PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Video Material has concluded that ``Adverse effects upon people, and especially upon children, of exposure to material containing various degrees of violence, pornography or obscenity have been demonstrated''.
The majority of the Select Committee strongly opposed the proposition for a new NVE (non-violent erotica) category, which would have entrenched X-rated video pornography.
All six State Governments have, through their Attorneys-General expressed unanimous opposition to the circulation of X-rated videos.
We consider the continuing distribution of X-rated videos from the A.C.T. to be reprehensible and to be contrary to the wellbeing of the Australian community in general.
We strongly request urgent Government action to prohibit the distribution of X-rated and excessively violent video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 217 citizens) and Parer (from 203 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament the petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration of mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.

Your petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and; prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

That we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no knowledge of that case.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

That X rated videos harm the community, especially women and children, as outlined in evidence given to the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. Your petitioners request that the Senate should pass a bill to prohibit the registration of X rated videos by the Commonwealth Censor.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Crowley (from 13 citizens) and Jones (from 27 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers, about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia. Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia.
(2) Ban the import of Cobalt-60 and Caesium-137 and Caesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products.
(3) Ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation (electron beam, X-ray etc.).
(4) Ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. I refer the Minister to the Saulwick Herald poll published in today's Sydney Morning Herald, which showed that almost 40 per cent of people polled believed interest rates were the most important factor in pushing up housing costs. Twenty per cent of people believed the cause was the presence of overseas buyers whilst 18 per cent believed it was the activities of speculators. Is the Minister aware that only 9 per cent of respondents blamed the housing crisis on availability of land? Why did the Government's housing summit last Friday focus on land availability, when the main cause of the crisis is clearly the failure of the Government's economic policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Actually, I have not seen the Saulwick poll in the Sydney Morning Herald, but I thank the honourable senator for drawing my attention to it. I will have a look at it.
—Here it is if you would like to have a look at it.
—I will have a look at it now, later or any time the honourable senator wishes me to; I will look at it.
—Would you like it now?

—If the honourable senator wants to give it to me now, I am quite happy. But I do not want to delay the Senate by looking at what he hands to me across the table five minutes after he has asked me a question when he could have handed it to me across the table five minutes before he asked the question.

ANSWER.PARA: The question Senator Boswell has asked seems to me to be an extraordinary question. He is saying that, according to this poll, a number of people in Australia believe one thing and a number of people believe that the solution to the problem is the availability or the supply side aspects of land for housing. The difference between perceptions and reality is the question that the honourable senator is asking. What is a clear analysis of the housing problem is that the supply side aspects of the problem are the most difficult and the ones for which there is the possibility of immediate relief. Frankly, I get sick and tired of members of the Opposition trotting out arguments about interest rates when it could be helping create a positive framework and a positive atmosphere in this country and doing something about the land supply problem which is a real aspect of the housing crisis in this country. The housing summit on Friday was aimed at doing something positive about that. If this were a conservative government-the people of Australia can thank God that it is not-it would have clamped down and created a recession. The demand and the overheating in the housing sector would have been dealt with that way and people would not have had access to housing.

What we as a government are doing is identifying the positive things that can be done to improve the supply side aspects-releasing land onto the market in Australia to make land more available, making it available to the States, asking the States to do the same and setting up mechanisms by which we identify other blockages in the supply side of the system such as the questions of skilled labour and housing materials. I will read Senator Boswell's poll, but it will not alter the fact that that is the positive, most pro-active policy a government in these circumstances can take.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to recent public comments about Australia's relations with the Soviet Union and in particular the press release by the Opposition spokesman for foreign affairs, Mr Spender, last Friday in which he asserted that the Government's policies towards the Soviet Union have been influenced by the alleged clandestine activities of the Soviet diplomat Zemskov, and implied that there has been a sinister relationship between Zemskov and a senior official of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's attitude to the issues and allegations that Mr Spender has raised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said last week, it is well-established practice that the Government does not comment on security and intelligence affairs. I will not depart from that practice any more than I did last week, to the obvious distaste of Senator Stone then and now and some other members of the parrot brigade opposite. But within that constraint there are aspects of the allegations made by the shadow Minister for foreign affairs and trade, Mr Spender, which do not go to the sources or nature of Australian intelligence information and on which I am able to comment as a result and indeed which I believe cannot be allowed to pass without a comment. At the outset let me make clear that the Australian Government's approach--
—Like the procedure for issuing a visa.

—I am happy to talk about that in general terms, but not in the context of any particular case, the scrutiny that was made of any particular individual in that context or the sources of information about that particular individual in that context. I do not propose to do that, but what I do propose to do is to respond to the allegations, not only those directed against the the officer of my Department, but also those which specifically claim that certain aspects of our dealings with the Soviet Union have in fact been influenced by a particular alleged role played by a particular Soviet official. What I want to say at the outset is that the Australian Government's approach in its relations with the Soviet Union is hard headed and realistic. It takes due account of the commercial benefits that flow from adopting a position of recognition of the practical benefits that can flow from a relationship in economic and trade areas-a relationship which we have not been afraid to develop-but it is an approach which is also based on advice from all relevant departments and agencies, including our security agencies, in the context of any advance in that relationship. Thus, the current fisheries and commodities negotiations with the Soviet Union have been undertaken with the fullest possible consultation with the defence and security agencies, and Australian security interests have been fully taken into account in the course of these negotiations. I believe that when the outcome of those negotiations becomes a matter of public record-it is already partly so-the force of what I am saying will be perfectly clear; indeed, it should be quite apparent.

ANSWER.PARA: The shadow Minister, in suggesting that Australia's relations with the Soviet Union so far as the consular agreement is concerned are somehow the product of an exercise that puts us at security risk-an exercise based on an allegedly sinister relationship between Zemskov and an Australian official-is making an absolutely preposterous assertion. I can say for the record that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation had no problems whatsoever with the consular agreement which has been concluded-that is to say, negotiated but not yet signed-between our two countries. Moreover, Mr Spender is absolutely wrong in suggesting, as he does in his press release, that the consular agreement will grant full diplomatic status to Soviet consular officers and do so in a way that is without precedent elsewhere in the world. That agreement provides immunity from criminal jurisdictions similar to that accorded to diplomats, but that does not amount to diplomatic status. Moreover, and perhaps more significantly in the light of the flavour that Mr Spender was seeking to convey in his press release, the kinds of immunities in question are not unusual in agreements of this kind; indeed, no lesser immunities have been granted for more than 20 years under specific consular treaties, not diplomatic ones, which the United Kingdom and the United States of America have with the Soviet Union.

Again, the immunities granted in the Australia-Union of Soviet Socialist Republics agreement-and this is part of the explanation of them, being cast as they are-are reciprocal in character and will apply equally to Australian consular staff in the event that Australia opens a consulate in the Soviet Union in the future. As I have said, one of the reasons they were negotiated on that basis was to acquire reciprocal status for Australia in the event that we might open such an office. So there is nothing unique, nothing unusual and nothing untoward about this agreement. It is quite grotesque for it to be suggested that this is not only something that will help the Soviets in a potential espionage activity but it is also somehow attributable to the relationship referred to in the press release.

Let me now turn to that relationship, because in Mr Spender's press release personal allegations have been made against a particular Australian official which are among the most shabby, despicable and utterly unsubstantiated to have come from the Opposition in recent memory. They represent a grossly unfair attack upon the officer concerned, who has served and continues to serve his country with diligence and dedication. The unambiguous purport of what Mr Spender is saying in his press release of last Friday is that there was a sinister relationship between Mr Hayden's former principal private secretary, namely, Mr Michael Costello, who is now a deputy secretary in my Department, and the Soviet official, Zemskov. Not the slightest foundation is given for that serious personal attack on a senior Australian career diplomat, nor to my knowledge is there any conceivable foundation for such an assertion. In making the allegation the shadow Minister refers only to a Canberra Times report of 5 February. He suggests, based evidently on that report, that the relationship between the Australian official and Zemskov is, in his terms, `a cause for particularly grave concern'. Mr Spender neglects to note that the very same report states that there was never any suggestion of impropriety. The report states that it was natural enough that Mr Costello should know Zemskov in view of his professional responsibilities in the Department for Australia's relations with the Soviet Union. Moreover, and this is completely ignored in the Spender release, on the following day the Canberra Times printed under the heading `Zemskov: clarification' a piece which states:
The Canberra Times reiterates that its original story did not suggest Mr Costello's conduct was anything but appropriate, professional and necessary to the execution of his duties.

So in basing his allegations on the newspaper report but neglecting-obviously deliberately-even to mention these clear and unequivocal subsequent statements by that same paper, the shadow Minister is clearly engaged in a malicious and quite dishonest attack, not to mention a highly actionable attack, upon the individual in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. To impugn a member's motives is clearly unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—I withdraw the reference to dishonest--
—What about `malicious'?

—Am I being asked to withdraw the reference to that as well? I will leave that to the courts to determine and withdraw it accordingly. What I can say about Mr Spender's attack is that it is an exercise in McCarthyism of a kind that we have not seen for a long time in this country. It is to the immense discredit of him personally and to the Opposition that he should have felt able to or compelled to make it.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, might I say for the record, as I believe the Prime Minister is saying in similar terms in the other place, totally rejects the allegations which have been made and affirms our complete confidence in the loyalty and integrity of this officer. Mr Costello emerges from this unhappy affair with his very substantial standing and reputation for competence and integrity quite untarnished. The shadow Minister emerges from this disgraceful episode even more than hitherto, if that is possible, an object of contempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. What are the Minister's views on the options outlined in the Institute of Family Studies report entitled Families and Tax in 1989?

—As I said to the Senate last week, my views in relation to the Institute of Family Studies are not particularly relevant to the issues that will be debated in a matter of public importance later this afternoon. My views, through the process of input to Cabinet discussions, are a matter for Cabinet's concern and certainly not a matter for public debate at this point.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How does the Government then view the options put forward by the Institute of Family Studies in its most valuable report?

—Along with a great many other positions that are being put forward-Senator Hill is aware of a number of positions that were put forward at the Women's Tax Convention on Saturday-the views of the Institute will be considered by the Government at the appropriate time. This Government, unlike the government of the Liberal-National Party coalition, is a government of consultation. It listens to and considers a wide range of issues that are presented to it. But it is not my position to pre-empt confidential issues that will be debated within Cabinet. I would have thought that Senator Hill would have been aware of that.

—Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of comments made last week in the House of Representatives by Mr Howard in which the Opposition Leader alleged that there were differences between the Minister and the Prime Minister on the effect that the Asian immigration debate had had upon business migration from Hong Kong? Will the Minister explain to the Senate the facts surrounding his reported comments in Hong Kong recently?

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. A question in almost the same terms was asked of the Minister and he gave us-I remember it-his reply a few days ago. I cannot see why we should be repeating these matters.
—Mr President, I rise on the point of order. I do not think the Leader of the Opposition read my reply.
—I will allow the question. I cannot remember whether it was identical.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the sensitivity. Usually if this issue is raised I am accused of opportunism for raising it. But I draw the attention of the Heckles and Jeckles opposite to Hansard of 2 March where Mr Howard decided to have a go on this particular issue. What particularly annoyed me was that the day before I had at least given an unequivocal answer clarifying those matters. Mr Howard chose to ignore that. Indeed, a close reading of Mr Howard's answer shows that he said that he relied on a newspaper report in the Melbourne Herald. He went on to quote that as my view-never quoting me directly-and tried to contrast that with the views of the Prime Minister. Coincidentally, he got both sets of views wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: I have had the opportunity to read the transcript of what I said in Hong Kong. Nothing I said there is in any way in conflict with what the Prime Minister said. Let me explain that very simply: The Prime Minister said in November that the Opposition's policies could cost Australia $350m in forgone business migration. This year's program will run under estimate and will cost us $350m. No claim was made then by the Prime Minister, nor now by me, that that is attributable entirely to one factor. What I said in Hong Kong was that there were three factors operating in our failing to achieve our business migration target: firstly, the appreciation of the Australian dollar; secondly, competition from New Zealand and Canada; and, thirdly, our image in the continent of Asia in particular due to the debate we had last year. I leant over backwards in Hong Kong to try to hose down the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —That must have been a fascinating sight.

—When Senator Powell gets 5.5 per cent of the vote in the Australian Capital Territory she can make asides and jokes against me; but not before. Metaphorically, I leant over backwards to try to hose down the issue and not to be too critical of the Opposition or anything else. What I then found was that the weakness in me-it must have been a weakness at the time-in trying to be generous to the Opposition was exploited by this pathetic excuse for an Opposition leader, who did not go to the source material but read just one newspaper and drew his contrast. How could that person seriously offer himself as a future Prime Minister of this country when his whole source of information was one unverified newspaper article that has subsequently been corrected by me in this chamber? Do not let Opposition members ever again accuse us of opportunism on this issue. Their own Leader has crossed that line. He knows quite well that there is no conflict. The sooner he leaves the matter alone, the better.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the operation of partnership with industry. Can the Minister confirm whether it is the case that when tenders are let by some Commonwealth departments those firms submitting tenders are requested to specify offsets, despite the fact that those who have signed partnership agreements with the Government are exempt from such obligations? Can the Minister inform the Senate why those departments are still requesting details of offset information? Can the Minister further inform the Senate as to what communication there has been between his Department and other departments about partnership agreements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the offset guidelines all tenders are subject to a specification of appropriate offsets. These have to be complied with for all eligible government purchasing. Firms which have undertaken partnership agreements are, as Senator Macklin points out, exempted from the offset obligations on the basis of a long term agreement which the partnership agreements represent. Thus firms which have entered long term agreements such as partnerships are exempted from offsets but all other overseas tenderers-that is to say, tendering companies which are not subject to partnership agreements-are required to specify how their offset obligations will be met. I think that explains why purchasing departments still require details of offsets from non-partnership tenderers-indeed, from all. The tender specifications go to a wide range of companies, some of which are partnership companies while others are not.

ANSWER.PARA: On the second part of the question, there has been extensive communication between my Department and other purchasing departments about these matters. The main vehicle for these communications has been the Government Offsets and Purchasing Advisory Committee, which is a part government-both State and Federal-and part business or industry committee. It has on it representatives from my Department, the Department of Administrative Services, the Department of Defence and State government departments. The Government's policy regarding offsets in well understood, I believe, within government departments. However, if Senator Macklin's question was prompted by a query from some more remote place, let me say that I willingly concede that a large number of purchasing officers are scattered widely across the many arms of government. There may be some lack of clarity about these procedures in some isolated instances, but I believe that that is generally not so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister a supplementary question: Would it not make sense for companies which have signed partnership agreements, when submitting tenders, to be exempt from providing the quite voluminous amount of material that is required with regard to offset obligations? As they are exempt from offset obligations, why are they required to go through that process?

—In some ways I concede that what the honourable senator is suggesting would make sense. Anything which requires somebody to fill out a form when that person does not have to does not make sense. I will certainly look into the matter. While it might make sense, from the point of view of the company, not to require companies to fill in those forms, it might not make any sense from the point of view of the administration of the offsets scheme across the board. It might, indeed, confer a particular advantage on partnership companies which they are not entitled to by virtue of being partners.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Are United Kingdom age pensions indexed in the United Kingdom but not indexed if the recipient settles in Australia? If so, does the Australian Government supplement the United Kingdom pensions of persons resident in Australia to counter the loss in real value of the pension due to non-indexation? What is the nature of the supplement which is provided and are such payments ex gratia or are the payments in accord with a provision of the Social Security Act? Has the Australian Government approached the United Kingdom Government to index its pensions for recipients now resident in Australia and, if so, when were those approaches made and when is some agreement likely?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information for Senator Colston from the Minister for Social Security. It is correct to say that United Kingdom age pensions are indexed in that country but are not indexed if the recipient moves to Australia and lives here permanently. That means that a former United Kingdom resident who has come to live in Australia has pension paid at the level it was when he or she left the United Kingdom or, if it was granted while that person was in Australia, at the time of the grant. Australian pensions, by contrast, are fully indexed in the United Kingdom. Accordingly, it has always been a matter of concern to this Government that the United Kingdom Government chooses not to index its pensions here, despite the fact that it does so in approximately 30 other countries. A United Kingdom pensioner, therefore, living in Australia may get as little as $5 a week from the United Kingdom Government, whilst someone living elsewhere, with an identical United Kingdom contribution record, could get the fully indexed amount of up to $185 a week. It is therefore costing Australia about $80m a year to subsidise the United Kingdom pension in Australia because of this refusal by the United Kingdom Government to index pensions.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Colston asked about the nature of supplementation and subsidisation. Subsidisation takes place under two different arrangements. The first and by far the largest group who are subsidised are those who have qualified for the Australian pension by meeting residency requirements, for example, 10 years for age pensioners, and so are paid under the Social Security Act in the same way that other pensioners are paid in Australia. For this group, normally the United Kingdom pension is treated as income under the income test. The second and smaller group are those who do not meet residency requirements but who are in the process of doing so. This group is paid under a social security agreement between Australia and the United Kingdom.

The last part of Senator Colston's question was about approaches made by the Australian Government to the United Kingdom Government on this matter. The Minister for Social Security raised the issue in talks with the United Kingdom Minister, Mr Nicholas Scott, in London in July last year. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, raised the issued again with the British Prime Minister, Mrs Thatcher, during her visit here in August last year. Subsequent to that, the Prime Minister wrote to Mrs Thatcher urging consideration of indexation. Her response, received in January, again declined to index pensions on the ground of cost to the United Kingdom Government. Finally, the Australian Government is committed to raising this issue with the United Kingdom Government at every possible opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Local Government: In view of the overwhelming concern of councils and shires throughout Australia about the clawback of additional revenue from rates on Australia Post and Telecom Australia, will she guarantee that no shire or council will be worse off as a result of that clawback?

—I have indicated in the Senate before that I am consulting widely with local government about this particular decision and I have also undertaken in this place and to local government generally that I will ensure that whatever is finally decided is done on the most equitable basis. I am aware of the concerns of local government but the decision that Australia Post and Telecom Australia should pay rates parallels the decision that Commonwealth business enterprises should pay payroll tax. It is important to remind Opposition senators, who keep raising this matter, that when I read Future Directions I see only that their commitment is to reduce public expenditure. Yet Opposition senators come in here with all the moral indignation they can muster and say that there should be more expenditure across a whole range of areas. Local government has a responsibility to rein in its expenditure in exactly the same way as State and Federal governments. I have undertaken that however this decision is finally implemented it will be done on the most equitable basis.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Are we to assume therefore that the answer to the question is no?

—The answer to the question is that I will ensure that local government is fairly treated on the same basis as the States but it has to accept responsibility. I will ensure that that is done on the most equitable basis. Perhaps Senator Messner and other Opposition senators do not understand the meaning of the word `equity'.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of recent press reports from overseas about human illnesses and deaths caused by the organism listeria monocytogenes in fresh cheeses? What action is being taken to protect the Australian public from this danger?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should thank Senator Black for not asking me the same question that Neil Kinnock asked the British Prime Minister in the House of Commons last month-that is, `What did you have for lunch?'. As I recall she replied, `Cheshire cheese-and very nice it was too'. I did not have cheese for lunch, but if I had and it had been something as exotic as King Island brie, Margaret River brie or even humble cheddar, being an Australian product it would have been very nice indeed and very likely free from any taint of listeria. I have seen the press reports, which were mainly of overseas contamination of cheeses by listeria. To my knowledge there have been no reports of any contamination of Australian cheeses. The reports have all concerned the organism listeria monocytogenes and it should be mentioned immediately that listeria itself is an organism that is naturally present in a variety of raw food ingredients of animal or plant origin. In fact, there are eight species of listeria. One of them, listeria inocula, is an additive in the cheese making process. But the offensive one, the culprit, the dangerous one which has caused ill health, sickness and, I believe, death in Spain last year, is listeria monocytogenes. As an organism it is destroyed by cooking or by pasteurisation. Thus, local cheeses made on the Australian market are not likely to have this organism present as they have either survived a heat treatment or been made from pasteurised milk. There may be some very small family backyard concerns that privately make a cheese or two to which this does not apply, but it certainly applies to the regular brands. The problems are generally associated with inadequate cooking or heat processing, or they can arise because of poor hygienic practices in the factory, shop or home after the necessary delivery of cheese has been made. It is a feature of soft cheeses, and not all cheeses, in which the food poisoning occurs.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has operated since January last year-indeed, I think that it was one of the first decisions that I made in this portfolio-to institute a control program on imported cheeses. All imported soft and surface ripened cheeses from factories identified overseas as potential sources of contamination are sampled upon arrival and are held until they are cleared. High risk cheeses are sampled and recall procedures are implemented if listeria is detected. Since the program four samples have tested positive. They have been destroyed by Quarantine under supervision and no recalls were necessary. For Australian produced cheeses all factories manufacturing high risk products are tested on a random basis under a Commonwealth and State program. There is in place a procedure agreed by the States and the Commonwealth for clearing plant and product if contamination is detected. None has up until now. If I had been asked what I had for lunch and it had been an Australian or an imported cheese, it would have been okay.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I refer the Minister to her refusal last week to nominate the reasoning behind those elements of the Government's economic policy which lead her to believe that the higher tax, higher spending program-oriented approach of the Women's Electoral Lobby is wrong and Mr Keating's approach is right because she did not want to muddy the waters before the women's tax conference. Now that the conference has been held, will the Minister answer the question and tell the Senate why the Government is right and the Women's Electoral Lobby is wrong?

—It is a great pity that Senator Vanstone was not at the Women's Tax Convention on Saturday. Had she been there, she would have been interested in the commonality of views that were put forward by a diverse range of organisations. I think that Senator Newman and Senator Hill would endorse my comments in this regard. I think Senator Vanstone would like me to say that I endorse the Women's Electoral Lobby or Women's Action Alliance or the Country Women's Association over the Government's strategy. Obviously I shall not do that. I shall listen to the views that have been expressed by those diverse women's organisations, and I shall take part in the discussions that they will be having in presenting their set of principles and recommendations to the Prime Minister on International Women's Day on Wednesday. I shall certainly be putting forward my views in conjunction with the views that have been expressed through the Women's Tax Convention in the appropriate place, in the Cabinet room. Senator Vanstone will have to wait for that outcome.

—Mr President, I put a supplementary question to the Minister: she does not appear to appreciate that the only connection between the women's tax conference and my question is that the comments of the Women's Electoral Lobby were put as a rider or explanation to the Lobby's paper. The tax-more, spend-more approach of the Women's Electoral Lobby was not at all a function or substantive element of the paper I am referring to. The comment was simply a rider at the end of the paper indicating that the Women's Electoral Lobby did not agree with the Government's general economic proposals.
—Order! This is a supplementary question, not a statement.

—I am not asking the Minister to pre-empt any Cabinet discussion on tax conference matters; I am simply asking her to defend her Government's approach against the view of the Women's Electoral Lobby. She has indicated thus far that she is not prepared to defend her Government's economic policy, and I give her another opportunity to do so.

—I feel that I have adequately answered Senator Vanstone's question. Obviously, I support the Government's policies. The Women's Electoral Lobby, like the Country Women's Association, the Women's Action Alliance and all the other organisations that made such worthwhile contributions through the tax convention, is entitled to have its views listened to. That is what will happen in the context of the discussions with the Prime Minister. In speaking last week, I had no intention of trying to pre-empt discussion by making grand pronouncements about them.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, concerns the steady deterioration in the urban environment. Is the Minister aware that the bulk of Sydney's sewage is poured into the ocean essentially untreated? Is the Minister aware that the infrastructure costs of Australia's capital cities are mounting and stressing the ability of State governments to meet them, leading to steady erosion of the quality of urban environments? Does the Minister support the Prime Minister's call for a 25 per cent increase in Australia's population in the next 10 years? If he does, does he accept that this will exacerbate the problems of urban decay? Finally, what additional help will the Federal Government provide to the States so that the costs of an expanded infrastructure can be met and the severe environmental damage caused by existing inadequate infrastructure, such as Sydney's totally inadequate sewage handling, can be redressed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware that the bulk of Sydney's sewage is poured into the ocean essentially untreated. It would be very difficult for any Sydneysider not to be aware of that at the moment, with demonstrations on the beaches and lifeguards threatening to withdraw their services. I am also concerned about it from the tourism point of view because it cannot be doing the tourism industry very much good. I am aware that infrastructure costs in the capital cities are mounting. I am asked whether I am aware that these cost increases are stressing the ability of State governments to meet such costs. All the State governments would certainly claim that they were being stressed to meet those costs. The truth of such claims I am not always sure of, but I am aware of them. I am asked whether I support the Prime Minister's call for a 25 per cent increase in Australia's population in the next 10 years. I have to confess a bit of ignorance here: I did not know he had made it. I will have to get some instructions on that; I am not sure.
—Have a go! Don't you have a mind of your own?

—I do not think my view on Australia's population growth in the next 10 years is entirely relevant. I am asked what additional help will be provided to the States. I guess that is the crunch question. So far I have not been approached by the States, in particular the State of New South Wales, with requests for any assistance. I am not at this stage aware of any other approach to the Government requesting assistance on the question of sewerage. Senator Walsh is probably anxious to meet any requests that come in, but it would be very difficult for me to commit the Government to help when we have received no such requests at all.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Prime Minister's statement was made on Friday and was quite widely publicised. Does the Minister accept that the substantial increase in the rate of Australia's population increase is stressing the ability of the States to provide urban infrastructure and that that is leading to a decay in the quality of urban life in Australian cities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Questions about population increase should be directed more properly to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, whose portfolio covers population increase matters. We all obviously have to be careful about the capacity of Australia to meet its needs in relation to population increases. What I think should be the rate is not relevant, but obviously the Government will monitor that increase. The Government will have to make sure that Australia can afford to take on new migrants. There are those who claim that a big intake will boost the economy; there are those who claim the opposite. I am not certain of the answer, so I will not give it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer the Minister to yesterday's Sunday television program on possible trials for war crimes. Does the Minister agree that, in light of the program, which spoke of a Mr Rover against a background of images of the most horrendous concentration camp scenes, if Mr Rover were to be tried he could not now be guaranteed a fair trial? Does the Minister agree that the program reinforces the fears expressed by many ethnic communities that such communities, rather than individuals, would be targeted? Does the Minister believe that the statement made on the program by the head of the Special Investigations Unit, Mr Greenwood, that in light of the investigations some individuals should not have been allowed to enter Australia prejudges the issues and sets a dangerous precedent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had some glimpses of the Sunday program when I was interstate and happened to switch on the television in my motel room. However, I did not see the whole program, so I cannot talk about the entire context as it may have been developed by the directors of that segment of the cover story.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said before, in answer to questions about a certain Australian citizen who was also named on the program and who faces expulsion from the United States, any publicity which can prejudice the fair trial of a person who may be charged in relation to these very serious offences is to be avoided, if at all possible. I would make a plea to the media of this country to exercise some self-restraint and some decency in this respect. As was indicated in the question, it is very important that the fountains of justice are not poisoned by pre-trial publicity.

As a Senate, when passing the war crimes legislation, we said, as is indicated in the preamble, that it is essential in the interests of justice that persons accused be given a fair trial with all the safeguards for accused persons on trial in our courts, having particular regard to matters such as the gravity of the allegations and the lapse of time since the alleged crimes. Certainly, the courts of this country have always taken care to protect an accused person against the possibility of a jury-there will be jury trials if committal proceedings are successful, from a prosecution's point of view-being prejudiced in its dealings with an accused person. What one would not wish to see is a trial not going ahead because of an indulgence in appeal to emotional reactions such as those foreshadowed in the Sunday program which I partially saw.

I do not believe that any reasonable person would think that the investigations being carried out by the Special Investigations Unit, the prosecutions to be undertaken or the Government's policy or indeed the Parliament's policy in eventually passing the legislation is directed against communities. Clearly attention is directed to those individuals who, it is indicated, have sought haven in this country, despite the fact that there are serious allegations concerning some of them. I make no indication that the persons named on the program are indeed the subject of investigation by the Special Investigations Unit or may be the subject of charges. The fact is that the allegations which may be made against certain persons in Australia are so serious that restraint, both in the media and in this chamber, is called for if persons are eventually to receive a fair trial.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the recent talks in Jakarta on Kampuchea. It appears that these talks failed to achieve significant results. Will Australia continue to bring pressure on the various groups involved in the Kampuchean question and use what influence it has on the Vietnamese for them to withdraw?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second Jakarta Informal Meeting (JIM) which was held between 19 February and 21 February did achieve some limited progress, attended as it was by the Association of South East Asian Nations countries plus Vietnam, Laos and the various Khmer factions. It did clearly and systematically identify the issues that need to be tackled, both internal and external. That, I think, is a tribute to my colleague Indonesian Foreign Minister Alatas, the Chairman of that meeting, who has been concerned to focus the parties on those issues of detail in a way that some of them have not in the past been prepared to do. It was also agreed on the need for an international conference and an international control mechanism to supervise a settlement, although details as to participation in that conference and its venue, and as to the role, function and size of an ICM do remain to be settled.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the greatest disappointment at the JIM meeting-this also was acknowledged by Foreign Minister Alatas-was the continuing failure of the Khmer factions to make headway on the internal aspects of a settlement, although they did agree of course to continue talks, with timing and venue as yet unspecified, and to report back to the JIM Chairman within four months.

So far as Australia's role in all of this is concerned, during my own visit to the region a few weeks ago-that is to say in the relevant countries, being for this purpose Vietnam, Laos, Thailand and China-and in my discussions with Foreign Minister Alatas last week, I have made clear Australia's interest as a concerned regional neighbour in the resolution of the Cambodia conflict and in the removal of a major cause of tension within the region, although I have repeatedly said that Australia does not claim to be a central player in this affair or to be really in a position of offering solutions to the present rapidly evolving situation. But in expressing Australia's interest I have been concerned to say a number of things: first of all, to express Australia's strong support for an early agreement on the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops and the cessation of external military aid; secondly, to express our unequivocal opposition to any return to power of Pol Pot or his senior associates in the Khmer Rouge; thirdly, to make clear our desire to see the Cambodian factions reach agreement among themselves on a durable internal settlement leading to elections and to do so as soon as possible; fourthly, to express support for Prince Sihanouk as a key figure whose incorporation in a leading role in any transitional Cambodian administration would really be crucial if it were to secure international acceptance; fifthly, to express our willingness to participate in an international conference if invited to do so; and, finally, our willingness to consider participation in an international control mechanism, but depending, of course, on the circumstances of the settlement and the proposed mechanism in question and our assessment of their respective viability.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Resources aware that, due to the drop in the price of gold, Central Norseman Gold Mines NL at Norseman in Western Australia is to close one of its underground operations, curtail production of its gold and as a result 70 workers are to be retrenched? Is he further aware that the company has reduced exploration to a level where it is only maintaining existing reserves of ore? As Central Norseman has been the one and only gold mine in Western Australia to operate continuously since 1935 during at least four downturns in the industry, does the Minister now recognise that in the light of the economically fragile condition of the industry the additional imposition of the corporate tax on gold will be a disaster? Will he attempt to advise the Treasurer to change his mind?
—They are closing it down because of the price of gold.
—Yes, I thought that that would get the Minister going.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time perhaps some of the Opposition senators will reveal where their investments might be-I exempt Senator Panizza from that-when this gold question comes up. After all, no other industry that produces a profit in Australia is exempt from tax like the gold industry is. The closing of that loophole is a necessary step in terms of economic efficiency and equity. And that is an important consideration. As I recall it, the price of gold hit a top of about $US477 per ounce in January 1988. It is now at around $US385 per ounce and, in Australian dollars, about $473 at present. On average, the cost of producing an ounce of gold is about $300 an ounce at present.
—Is that the same for open cut and for deep mining?

—On average, those are the production costs in Australia, involving all forms of mining. Obviously some forms are cheaper and some forms are more expensive. As I understand it, Norseman is deep mining, so its costs could be at the upper end of that. In Australian dollar terms at present, gold is about $473 per ounce and the average production cost is around $300 per ounce. So there still ought to be a healthy margin for gold producers. I am aware that, at a time in which prices have fallen, as they have since the top in January 1988, there is an increasing impetus on companies to rationalise and to amalgamate. That is the working out of the market. In all these issues the international price is a key determinant as to whether investment is committed or production is continued. The reasons for the slump in gold prices are, to say the least, fairly complex. Some of the reasons would be: the United States dollar has appreciated in real terms recently; there are lower inflationary expectations in the United States; there has been a reduction in international tensions; and there has been an increase in gold supplies.

ANSWER.PARA: Gold is a counter-cyclical commodity. When things turn good the price of gold tends to go down; we know that from our own experience. We also know from our own experience that, although the strengthening of the Australian dollar has given some relief to mining producers over the last few weeks, production costs in Australia have risen. I do not like to see anyone put out of work anywhere at any time, but gold is a commodity traded internationally on an international price and, when those prices fall, we expect those industry fluctuations.

I am pleased to say that the honourable senator yet again has shrunk from calling it a gold tax, as he knows that it is simply not that; it is merely an extension of company tax to the goldmining industry and the closing off of a long-running loophole. It is not having any impact at present for the simple reason that it does not yet operate. As I understand it, the analysts still predict that goldmining in Australia will peak in around 1990-91.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government received any new advice as to the correctness of its net fiscal position? What is that advice and from where has it been received?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has received confirmation of the fundamental soundness of its economic policy from not so much an extraordinary source but from a surprising source-indeed, from the shadow Treasurer pro tem. In today's Australian Robert Hadler wrote:

ANSWER.PARA: Responding to Mr Keating's taunts, Mr Peacock promised that a Federal Coalition government would aim to have a sufficient Budget surplus, after tax cuts, to offset all Commonwealth and State borrowings.

In the jargon that Treasury officials are fond of using, that means a net public sector borrowing requirement of either zero or a negative net PSBR. That is not something that this Government aims to do; it is something we have already done. It is nice to have from the mouth of the shadow Treasurer that the ambitions of a future coalition government are to achieve what this Government has already done. If I may say so, along with a refusal to make any specific commitments to tax cuts-we have become used to that-that was the only hard statement, so far as I could detect, in the whole interview. The rest of it was fairy floss, which would not surprise anybody very much who has been listening to Mr Peacock recently-if, indeed, anybody has been listening. It should not surprise listeners because, as Mr Peacock himself has said, he does not bring an accountant's approach to putting a Budget together.

That statement, of course, is incompatible with Mr Peacock's call, as recently as last Tuesday, for a tighter fiscal policy. I presume that the incompatibility is due to Mr Peacock not knowing that there are two perspectives to fiscal policy-one is the revenue side and one is the expenditure side. Mr Peacock probably does not know that. He sees only one component of it. If he does not want to take a tutorial from somebody in my office, from the Treasury or from somebody else in the bureaucracy, perhaps we could arrange for him to have a tutorial from Dr Hewson on that.

The only other point I make is that Mr Peacock said in that same article that the Opposition's policy on taxation will be released well before the next Federal poll is called, unless there is a poll before June 1989. Mr Howard, of course, had already promised to release that taxation policy in August 1988. That is a promise that is unfulfilled by some five months. Mr Howard now seems to be sliding out of any commitment to introduce or publish the Opposition's tax policies-that is assuming it has one-other than on the death knell before the next Federal election.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In the Australian newspaper on 15 February the Minister was quoted as saying that he does not believe a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport can be constructed in three years. As the Minister would be aware, the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support has claimed in the other place that an entirely new airport can be constructed at Badgerys Creek in that time. Does the Minister support that view? Have all necessary environmental impact statements been completed for the airport development at Badgerys Creek? If so, will the Minister supply copies? If not, when does the Minister expect them to be completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for the question. I take great pleasure in answering it. Mr Punch did say that he thought an airport could be constructed in three years at Badgerys Creek. Honourable senators would find that one of Australia's leading engineering companies bore that fact out last week by saying that it could do one in 3 1/2 years. So I do not think we have much argument about whether it can be done. As far as environmental impact statements on Badgerys Creek are concerned, my predecessor, Mr Cohen, was satisfied with the environmental impact process carried out at Badgerys Creek. I shall endeavour to rummage through the records to see what I can give Senator Brownhill a copy of in that respect. So far as the construction of a third runway at the existing airport is concerned, the difficulty is not the construction period but that there would need to be an environmental impact process. Looking at Botany Bay and its importance, all I can say is that it would be a very lengthy process. One would imagine that, given the controversial nature of the project, it would have to involve a very long public period. We could not simply shut it off behind closed doors: there would need to be a public hearing. I would estimate that an environmental process of that kind would take between one and two years-leaning more towards the two than to the one. That being the case, those comments that have been made by our Ministers about the respective times when something could be ready at Badgerys Creek as against Kingsford-Smith are correct.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think the process at Tullamarine took some 12 years. Have environmental impact studies been done for the roadwork development that will need to be undertaken to make Badgerys Creek accessible to the anticipated volume of traffic, given that the present road infrastructure is totally inadequate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point to make to Senator Brownhill is that the Sydney link road, as it is called, which is being widely promoted by the New South Wales Government, would not require any Federal environmental process. We would need some sort of link to that road. I doubt very much whether it would be necessary to have an environmental process for such a link; it would depend upon where the link would be. We would have plenty of time for that to go ahead. The environmental process involved in that would be much shorter than it would be for a runway going out into Botany Bay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the column `Inside Running' in the Weekend Australian of 4-5 March this year. In this column there is a reference to a recent visit which I made to defence establishments in Queensland where I found, among other problems, that there are serious deficiencies in the provision of men's and women's uniforms. I also referred to problems that exist with the Army's new 105 millimetre field artillery gun, the Hamel. The report says that the `Hamel guns are missing an important component-bullets!'. What should have been written was my report that the gun was missing a rather important component-shells; that is, it did not have the shells to meet the maximum range capability of this excellent weapon, and it will not have this capacity until at least three years after the Government gets around to making a decision to give priority to its production.
