Perhaps the Prime Minister did not even think that it was worth while providing a copy of the draft to his Minister advising for her advice. If he did give it to her a fortnight ago, that is an even greater indictment of her. As we are to have the privilege, apparently, of her contributing to a debate on the status of women, on this rare occasion, she might tell us whether she has had that report for a fortnight and explain to the Senate why she is not prepared to address a document by such a highly regarded body which, in the terms of this motion, expresses a concern about the bias that exists within the Government's tax system against families and the sharp fall in real disposable income suffered by most families under six years of hard Labor. It is being celebrated with evidence of a growing rejection by Australian women of Labor and an even greater rejection by Australian women of the Prime Minister. I am sure that this Government would like to be reminded that the rating of the Prime Minister in the eyes of Australian women collapsed last month from 41 per cent to 29 per cent-only 29 per cent of Australian women now support this Prime Minister, as disclosed by the Saulwick poll last weekend.

SPEECH.PARA: Why are the women of Australia rejecting the Prime Minister so? I suggest that it is because he is arrogant and out of touch. How out of touch will be demonstrated during this debate. He is offensive, as was shown in his response to the many thousands of Australian women who protested against this Government's policy on the pornographic video industry in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). He had no respect for the views those women were putting or for the views of the women's organisations that Senator Reynolds, time and time again, comes into this chamber and tells us that she wishes to hear and will respond to. But when a practical application comes to the test, Senator Reynolds does not even note the objections of these women's organisations. Perhaps she will respond to that in today's debate. As I have indicated before, on the issue of her Government's attitude to the demeaning of women by the pornographic video industry, she will not even front up or contribute to debates. Australian women are rejecting this Prime Minister because he is condescending and perhaps also because he gets no help whatsoever from the Minister assisting him, Senator Reynolds.

As I have said, this country has had six years of Labor government, during which time the women of Australia have been bombarded with a most sophisticated and expensive propaganda campaign telling them what this Government is doing for them. We have seen it in the form of continual surveys and conferences and glossy pamphlets, one after another. We have seen it in the form of strategically placed grants to particular organisations to try to get them involved in a project which the Government says is for their benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all rhetoric.

—It is all rhetoric, as my colleague says. The effect of this propaganda campaign has been simply to build expectations. But now the women of Australia are saying, `We have had enough of having our expectations built up by this Government. Where are the programs that should have been implemented to meet the rhetoric?'. The programs simply are not there. All we have seen instead has been this continual propaganda exercise. Let us consider health, for example. The Government sought from women what the key health issues were. It produced a booklet called Women's Health: A Framework for Change. The booklet sets out the problems, but where are the answers? The Government says, `They are yet to come, but we can promise you that they will come this year, because it is an election year'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government involved the Country Women's Association in identifying the particular problems facing rural women, a sector of the community that has been overlooked by this Government. What did it produce? It produced another booklet, Life Has Never Been Easy. Where are the answers? Senator Reynolds has taken on a special consultant to produce answers which will become part of this Government's election policy to be released later this year. In other words, the answers are not there. The policies are not being delivered. Yet rural women have had their expectations built up. They have been told that they have been part of this highly important exercise.

We have now had two women in advertising conferences, building expectations that the sexist stereotyping of women will end. Women have been brought from all around Australia to attend and participate in these conferences outlining the problem. But what has happened? Has anything happened? It certainly has not. When we look at the Government's own performance in its own arena we find that sexist advertising is still continuing in relation to the Royal Australian Navy. We find that this Government, which has dictated that the private advertising sector should lift its game in relation to sexist advertising and stop stereotyping women in the kitchen, is, at the same time through its legislative framework, supporting the pornographic video industry in the Australian Capital Territory. Forty-five thousand Australians have already petitioned this Parliament for this Government to act in accordance with the unanimous resolution of the Attorneys-General of this country, including the Government's own Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), to close the loophole and remove the ACT as the one remaining place in Australia from which this industry can operate and women can be demeaned in that degrading way. Will this Government respond to that? No, it will not. Yet at the same time it has the gall to say to the advertising industry, `You must lift your game'. What we say and what the women of Australia say is that this Government should start in provinces that are directly under its control, but it is failing to do so.

We have seen expectations built up in relation to part time work. In 1986 there was a conference on legislative and award restrictions to women's employment. What happened? Nothing. We are now told that the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government are finally negotiating towards this restructuring. Surprise, surprise! In an election year this matter is back on the agenda again, but what has been achieved? Very little.

We have identified, as this Government has identified, that there are particular problems relating to migrant women. What does this Government do? In 1985 the Government held a conference-surprise, surprise! The National Conference on Immigrant Women's Issues was held in 1985. What has happened since then? Again, Mr Deputy President, very little except that before Christmas last year Senator Reynolds called the key women within these groups to have another talk about what might be done to achieve the Government's objectives. This has been the practice of this Government: raise the profile of these areas that are critical to women but do not provide solutions, do not provide policies and do not provide programs to implement answers to these concerns. The Government's approach has all been about identification. Nothing has been done that is actually worthwhile for women. It is not surprising that Australian women are now rejecting this approach, recognising that they have been conned by this Government and saying that they have had enough. That is why the support for the Prime Minister has plummeted and support for this Government by Australian women has fallen so dramatically in recent times. Australian women realise that they have been conned and they will not let it continue.

Opposition senators have referred in the last few days to the important report put out by the Australian Institute of Family Studies entitled Families and Tax in 1989, which the Minister has yet to address. Perhaps we could draw to her attention in this debate some of the key findings of that important independent inquiry. They include that under this Government average tax rates have risen for most families and that those rises have been greater for families compared with single persons. They have been greater for those on middle incomes than for those on high incomes. I should remind honourable senators that this Labor Government is the one which provided extra tax relief for the most wealthy in this country while people in lower and middle income groups were allowed to suffer. The report states:
Since 1984-85, real disposable incomes have fallen sharply for all income units dependent on one income.

What about families with children? The report looks at a family consisting of two parents and four children. Their real disposable income has fallen more than $47 since 1984-85. That is why these families are hurting. That is why women are rejecting this Government. This has been caused not only by bracket creep but also by a decline in the real value of family concessions, namely, family allowances, the dependent spouse rebate and the sole parent rebate. During the short time that Senator Reynolds was present at the Women's Tax Convention on Saturday the women of Australia and women's organisations reinforced their concern that the real value of these allowances that reflect the cost to families of bringing up children has been disregarded by this Government.

We have seen a lack of support for families, a lack of recognition of the growing poverty of women, a total failure to understand what interest rates are doing to families and the need to house families, and a total lack of understanding of what is happening to families under this Government's inflation rate, with the cost of living families are having to to bear. Although no doubt the Minister in this debate will say that this is a family issue and not a women's matter, I would say to the Minister that, if she asks women whether they regard it as being particularly in their consciousness, they say that it is, because they are primarily concerned with the interests of their families and not just of themselves. The Minister should address that aspect rather than trying to find flippant ways of avoiding the problem.

It is not just the Institute of Family Studies that has been saying these things to the Government. I wonder whether the Minister has read the report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission that came out a week or so ago on homeless children. Judging by the precedent, one would suspect that she has not. I invite her, when she finds time with her other pressures, to read page 105 of that report, which again talks about the stress on families and the effect that that is having on family breakdowns as part of the difficulty of homeless children in our community. The report adopts a submission on the lines:
We-
that is, this Government-

are prepared to provide economic support when a family breaks down, but not the support services which might have prevented the breakdown. We expect the family to take the lion's share of caring for its dependent members without providing the support necessary for it to do so.

That has been the approach of this Government and it is related to the frightening level of homeless children in our community. Although the Minister denies it, that is also related to the growing level of domestic violence that is occurring in our community. If this Government started by addressing the cost and stress in economic pressure on families, it would be taking a worthwhile step towards resolving some of these awful situations that exist in our community.

If the Minister says that these reports have some out only in the last couple of weeks, I remind her of her Government's chief economic advisory report in October last year. It is worth repeating what the Economic Planning Advisory Council said in its report and advice to the Government:

. . . the evidence suggests that many low income people, especially families with children, have to survive on insufficient nutrition, are unable to heat their homes in winter, are often unable to afford medication, and are denied most forms of recreation.
Could there be a worse indictment of this Government than that statement from its chief economic advisory body? The report continued:

In many instances, there may be long-term adverse consequences for the education, health and employment opportunities available to such families. . . . The proportion of families with children in relative poverty has been higher during the 1980s than in the previous decade.
So the report goes on. What note did the Government take of that advice? Obviously, it took none at all.

We on this side of the chamber say that we have had enough of the propaganda. Women are rejecting this Government because it has not produced programs to match its propaganda and its rhetoric. The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women said last week, `Come to the women's tax conference on Saturday because we as a government will sit back and listen to the Australian women. We will not be participating in it because we want to receive advice from women'. We went along to the conference, and what did we find? It was opened by Minister Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. What did he say to the 200 women and me? He said:
. . . we should remember that there have been unparalleled initiatives to advance the status of women in the past six years . . .

He then proceeded to bucket the Opposition. If we wonder why the Primary Industries Minister was asked to open the conference, perhaps we had some indication when he tried to draw a parallel between the women's movement and farming. He spoke of women and their resource use. It was not surprising that he left the conference as soon as he had finished his address and that Senator Reynolds left not much later. If Senator Reynolds had remained at that conference, let me quote some of the things she would have heard from the women's organisations that she should have been listening to rather than avoiding. No doubt the Minister would say that she listens to the Women's Electoral Lobby (WEL). The paper received from that body states:
Families with children, as a category, have lost out over the last few years and should be seen as a priority group for assistance.
But they have not. The paper states further:
The loss of income by families with children over the last five years comes from the following factors:
1. The loss in value of Family Allowances-as these have not been indexed or increased since the advent of this Government.
I remind honourable senators that it was WEL advising Senator Reynolds on these points. The paper continues:
2. The loss of family allowances for families with joint income over the limit . . .
3. Increases in child-care fees for many families due to changes in the funding system in 1985 . . .
4. The fact that cuts in income tax have been primarily directed at higher-income-earners with no compensatory payments for most dual- (but relatively low-) income earners.
5. The rapid increase in housing costs and interest rates which fall primarily on households with younger children . . .
6. The general fall in real wages which will affect spending power in larger households more than smaller households, as children are additional consumers.

The Minister ought to listen to this advice rather than lecture this chamber. But this advice did not come only from WEL. All the submissions have the same theme. For example, the Catholic Women's League said:
We believe that for many families the present tax system is not collecting ``surplus wealth'' but rather household income which the family requires to sustain an independent and dignified lifestyle.

That is the sort of advice to which the Minister ought to listen. I do not have time in this debate to go through all the submissions, but they were presented to the Minister at the conference. The Catholic Women's League, Women in Management, the Country Women's Association, the Australian Family Association, the Women's Action Alliance, the Young Women's Christian Association and the Union of Australian Women all said basically that families and the women in them have suffered the most under this Government and that the Government has ignored their pleas. That is why they are now rejecting the Minister, the Government and the Prime Minister. We find that the Minister takes little notice of submissions from women's organisations. If she has not had the time to read the submissions, perhaps she could concentrate simply on the recommendations that were received at the end of the conference, because they recognise the Government's failings in this area.

The first proposition is that the cost of children be given greater financial recognition in the tax-social security transfer system. It is further recommended that the majority of women be given credit in their tax system for the costs they bear and the families they support; that children be recognised within the family system; and that the cost of children be properly recognised. The recommendations also condemn the Government for its higher education contribution scheme and say that it is about time that the Government did something about women's tax concessions. Above all, the report came down to an analysis of the fact that the value of unpaid work by women in the home who are supporting children is not recognised and that women and families simply cannot afford to maintain and bring up children in the style to which they would like to be accustomed, a style which we on this side of the chamber say they deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator REYNOLDS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity for this debate to take place this afternoon. We have heard what can be described only as a rave of misrepresentation by Senator Robert Hill. I will go through some of the points he made which totally misrepresented either this Government or individual members of the Government. Let me start with his comments about the popularity of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I am prepared to present him with a copy of an article about the support for Mr Hawke and Mr Howard as leaders. I assure Senator Hill that the Liberal Party, rather than having a gender gap, has what can only be described as a leadership gap. According to the article to which I refer, indicators showed that political support for Mr Hawke in February was 41 per cent, while that for Mr Howard was 19 per cent. It is quite clear which leader the women of Australia prefer.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill referred to a poll, but was not honest enough to give the details which I have in front of me. Forty-one per cent of women gave Mr Hawke a good or very good rating. Only 20 per cent gave Mr Howard a good or very good rating. Only 14 per cent of women gave Mr Hawke a poor or very poor rating, and-surprise, surprise-39 per cent rated Mr Howard poor or very poor. If Senator Hill wants to attack the Prime Minister, to misrepresent the way Australian women feel are thinking in relation to his leadership and commitment to policies that benefit women in so many areas, that is entirely a matter for him. However, I place on the record the very clear figures given by opinion polls.

I move now to Senator Hill's comments about X-rated videos, though what relevance they have to this debate I am not sure. Again, Senator Hill misrepresented the views of Australian women when he said in effect that they condemn the Government with respect to this matter and that this is an indication of lack of support. I have before me a letter from the National Women's Consultative Council which I will read in its totality. It is addressed to Senator Hill and states:
NWCC AND X-RATED VIDEOS
At the end of last year you were interested in the views of my Council on X-rated videos.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you really say `my council'?
—It is from Anne O'Byrne, the Convener. It is her council. She is the chairperson. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: After substantial debate it emerged that some members were opposed to X-rated videos . . .

Of course. It continues: others were more concerned about the matter of censorship, and all were concerned about the effect of violence in videos. Of course, violence in videos is an issue of concern to all of us. The letter continues:
It can be seen that the views were very mixed which I feel reflects the diverse views of the organisations which Council members represent.
I am prepared to table the speech of my colleague Mr John Kerin at the tax forum. I do not recall his making any attacks on the Opposition at that forum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read it again, lady.
—I am certainly prepared to table it.
—I will give you the reference.

—I do not propose to read the statement in its entirety, but it was a very positive statement. It dealt mainly with Government policy; it certainly was not a slamming attack on the Opposition. It was far more concerned with setting out the Government's policies.
—It says, `The Opposition, which has traditionally struggled to find anything meaningful at all to say'. Isn't that an attack on the Opposition? Read it!
—I think Senator Hill is being unnecessarily sensitive if one sentence in a speech of six or seven pages . . .
—It was a conference for you to turn up at and listen to women.
—Well, I did. I do not like to be pedantic about these things, but only two members of the Federal Liberal Party attended the convention. About six Australian Labor Party members attended.
—What about the State Liberals?

—There may have been State Liberals present. The point is that I object to Senator Hill's misrepresenting my attendance. I attended and left at half past one. The Senate may be interested to know why I left. I left because I had an appointment to meet with the Social Responsibility Department of the Mothers Union of the Anglican Church to discuss issues relating to Filipino brides. I assure Senator Hill that I did not leave to go to the Black Opal or for any frivolous reason. I certainly object to being misrepresented in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now address the report of the Institute of Family Studies, which Senator Hill seems to think I should have read by now. No, I have not read the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incredible!
—Quite clearly, the Opposition does not understand the way in which responsibilities are allocated. Brian Howe is the Minister directly responsible.
—What about the status of women? Aren't they concerned about such matters?

—I have responsibility across a range of portfolios, but I certainly am not able to read every report across 29 portfolios as well as my own. If Senator Newman is interested in listening, Minister Howe, in the other place, has brought down a statement about the report. I will read some of the points he has made. He says, as I have said, that the Government welcomes all contributions to policy discussion and development. This Government, more than any other, has encouraged consultation. We welcome all submissions which have become common each year as part of the Budget process. The Institute of Family Studies report is the theoretical study of the effect of the tax transfer system, the interaction of the tax and social security systems. Its analysis is no more than that. As the report itself makes clear, it refers to hypothetical couples on average weekly earnings. It does not take into account important social wage measures.
—This is not a hypothetical situation.
—They're hypothetical people!
—I wonder whether Senator Walters and Senator Tambling have considered implementing the social wage contributions of Medicare, superannuation or education. Mr Howe obviously has. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Medicare: If you have children you need health insurance. Medicare is worth $21 a week for AWE family.
Superannuation: This Government, with ACTU, has made superannuation widely available to ordinary families.
That is worth approximately $14 a week. He goes on:

Education: . . . Nearly 30% more children are staying on to year 12 because of the Government's policies. AWE family with one year 11 student and 2 younger children will get over $32 per week in Austudy-a total of $67 compared-with the . . . alleged tax loss for two-child AWE families of $27-$34 a week.

Social policy is not built on hypothetical examples. The other issue which is of concern to us is that the Social Security Review highlighted needs for social policy to consider all families-couples with children and with one or two incomes; sole parent families; unemployed families; kinship groups. About 11 per cent of families earn between $20,000 and $25,000. Only 7 per cent of income units are the Opposition's `typical family'-a `typical family' which lives in a magnificent mansion, on a quarter acre block, with a beautiful white picket fence, as is depicted in the picture on the cover of the Future Directions document. It is quite clear from the figures which Mr Howe has presented that those families on which the Opposition purports to have written its entire policy paper constitute only a small percentage.

Let me now detail some of the facts, because facts were rather short in Senator Hill's contribution. In the seven years of the Howard-Fraser regime, payments for children in low income families were increased once. In 1980 payments was increased from $7.50 per week to $10-the only increase for low income families in seven years, while economic policy deliberately threw families out of work. The results were devastating. By 1983 one in five Australian children lived in poverty. In 1976, 373,000 children were in low income families and by 1983 this figure had grown to 830,000.

The response of the Hawke Government in six years stands in clear contrast. We have increased pension and benefit rates in every year of our term-in 1983 from $10 to $12; in 1984 from $12 to $14; in 1985 from $14 to $16; in 1986 from $16 to $17; in 1987 from $17 to $22 for younger children and $28 for older children and in 1988 from $22 to $24 for younger children and $28 to $31 for older children.

The progress is there to see. Under Howard, in seven years, there was one increase from $7.50 to $10. In the same period, prices increased by 104 per cent. So in real terms payments fell by 35 per cent. We have increased payments to $31 for teenage children. That is a real increase of 108 per cent. For younger children we have increased payments to $24, which is a real increase of 61 per cent.

Clearly, a number of the statistics which have been quoted by Senator Hill are very much open to question. But the measures which the Hawke Government has adopted within the tax and social security system to reduce the impact of high effective marginal tax rates are not open to question. I will read through a number of these measures and am prepared to table the document. The three pages which I have before me detail, on a month by month and year by year basis, what has been done to reduce the impact of high effective marginal tax rates:

May 1983-Introduction of Family Income Supplement (FIS), as a payment to low income working families meant that in most cases families receiving FIS were better off working than receiving unemployment benefit . . .

1983-84-Increase in the Sole Parent Rebate from $713 to $790 a year: the Sole Parent Rebate, because it is not income-tested, acts as a workforce incentive by giving sole parents a higher taxfree threshold.
1983-84-Pensioner tax rebate was increased from $167 to $250 a year.
March 1984-Increase in the benefit income test fee area from $10 a week to $20 a week, and an increase in the upper limit of the 50 per cent taper from $60 to $70 a week.

1984-85-Beneficiary tax rebates were introduced at $50 a year for single beneficiaries and $75 a year for married beneficiaries. The Dependent Spouse Rebate was extended to de facto couples, thereby protecting certain beneficiaries.
1985-86-Beneficiary tax rebate increased from $50 to $170 a year for single beneficiaries and from $75 to $220 a year for married beneficiaries.
May 1986-Increase in the benefit income test free area from $20 to $30 a week.
1986-87-Beneficiaries tax rebates were increased from $170 to $190 a year for single beneficiaries and from $220 to $280 a year for married beneficiaries.

December 1986-Increase in the income tax threshold from $4,595 to $5,100 a year flowed through fully to pensioners and beneficiaries as the nominal value of the pensioner and beneficiary rebates was maintained.
1987-88-Married beneficiary tax rebate was increased from $280 to $430 a year.
The list goes on. I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In conclusion, it is important to ask: What is the Opposition's policy in relation to tax? What is its policy in relation to social security? All we get is this very glossy, attractive document. Senator Hill was the one who, a short time ago, talked about glossy documents produced by the Government but I cannot see that any of our documents really compare with the gloss and the shine on this beautiful document here that shows the perfect family. When one opens it up and tries to find out just what the Opposition is planning in relation to its policies, it is very difficult to determine; because in one breath--
—It is not a policy document, that is why.
—It is not a policy document? I thought it was a policy document. If it is not a policy document, I am not quite sure what it is. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: In Government, Liberal-National policies and decisions will be guided by five `Key Principles':
Strengthening the family.
Restoring people's control over their own lives.
Providing more incentive and choice.
Ensuring a fair go for all.
Building one Australia.
The Opposition does not really spell out how it is going to do this, but I am concerned with this comment at the bottom of the page:
Smaller government with less interference and lower taxes will provide the incentive that is so necessary to achieve that goal.

I wonder how smaller government will help families in need? I wonder how small government will provide much needed services? I wonder how smaller government will maintain the commitment that the Hawke Government has given to job creation? I wonder how smaller government will help in relation to housing policy, education policy and child-care policy? I think it would be salutary for members of the Opposition to take note of the fact that at the Tax Convention the idea of tax rebates for child-care or tax deductability was overwhelmingly rejected, income splitting was overwhelmingly rejected and there was an overwhelming rejection by women attending the Tax Convention of a downgrading of public services.

TALK.START.PARA: —How come you have been given a brief on that but you haven't been given a brief on the main paper?

—If Senator Tambling had been listening he would know that I read from comments that Mr Howe has just made in the other place on the particular matter that the honourable senator has raised. In conclusion, I find the matter of urgency that has been brought on for debate this afternoon a complete sham. The Hawke Government is very proud of its record. We know that there are families in need and we are working in the context of a wage-tax debate to protect families on middle and low incomes. We have made that clear on a number of occasions since the middle of last year. I believe that the convention that was held on Saturday has further enhanced the opportunities for the Government to consider fully the views of women and that is what we will be doing. The Prime Minister has given that commitment because he will be meeting with them on Wednesday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that there is a need for the restructuring of the tax system in the interests of families. That is the first point made in the matter of urgency moved by Senator Hill. The Australian Democrats support this motion but, once again, in somewhat different terms-which I will explain in the short time available to the Democrats in this debate-from what we believe is proposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it clear at the outset what we are talking about when we talk about the family. To the Democrats the family means a group in the community where there is the presence of children. All too often the family is viewed in narrow terms. The Liberals would have us see the family as depicted in their glossy document Future Directions, which Senator Vanstone assured us just a few minutes ago is not a policy document. It is more a publicity gimmick, I would suggest. It depicts an idealised mum and dad and two kids being rather cosy in an upper middle-class home which they own with dad bringing home the bacon, mum keeping the home fires burning and with single income home owning families being a minority among families in our community. What we have been offered by the Opposition, if we have been offered anything in terms of policy, is really picket fence politics. Apparently we are going to have to suffer that through the rest of this election year, a thought which is a little daunting. However, we want to make it clear that we are talking about all those family units in our community which vary very much and which provide an enormous challenge to all policy makers. Perhaps that is one reason why there does not seem to be much policy being made by the Opposition. There is no doubt either that there has been a fall in real disposable incomes, which is the other issue addressed in Senator Hill's motion. We need go no further than the report of the Australian Institute of Family Studies last week. Under the heading `Summary' it states:

In 1988-89 dollar terms, the same AWE family is now paying $30.80 per week more tax than they did 12 years ago compared to the twice AWE single person who is paying $18.88 more and the single person on four times AWE who is paying $105.32 less.

That is just one example. Examples abound across income and family groupings to demonstrate that real disposable incomes have fallen sharply for all units with dependants in particular. Those are the people whom we are concerned about today.

The Democrats remind the Senate that this is not only the result of tax rates. I also inject into this debate the fact that the Democrats were the only ones who, at the time, opposed tax cuts for high income earners which Senator Hill now seems to view after the fact, as is so often the case from that side of the House, with high dudgeon. The lower real income levels are also the result of considerable wage restraint which has been accepted by working people in our community, the hardest hit being the low and middle income earners while executive salaries, as has often been noted recently in debates, seem to have soared regardless. It is also an effect of the growth of part time work. The Government puts forward the increase in jobs consistently when the figures come through on employment, but we must remember that a great deal of that employment is part time employment which does not do a great deal to improve the incomes of people who are dependent upon that part time work.

One major issue pointed to both in the Australian Institute of Family Studies report and at the Women's Tax Convention is bracket creep. This is where I ask my first question of the mover of this motion, as well as of the Government. I ask it as a member of a political party that has consistently since 1977 had a policy of indexation of taxation levels, the only party which has. My question is: how will the Opposition deal with that? Will it index? I noted some quite equivocal remarks on that matter by the Opposition Treasury spokesperson, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), in this morning's Australian newspaper. Once again, the Democrats stand alone.

In general we are fascinated by Senator Hill raising in this matter of urgency today and in a barrage of questions in recent days of the Minister for Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Reynolds) matters regarding family income and in particular the Australian Institute of Family Studies report because of the numbers of questions that raises about the Opposition's policy. I will begin with the report of the Australian Institute of Family Studies and then I will move on to additional significant recommendations from the Women's Tax Convention held here last Saturday to which the issues addressed by the Institute of Family Studies were also central. The components of the Australian Institute of Family Studies tax package incorporate significant changes to tax scales which I will not detail here at the moment. They are changes which are designed, unlike tax changes which we have had so far, to support and assist low and middle income groups and include a continuing 49c in the dollar top rate on income above $45,000 a year and changes to family rebates. The introduction of a new income tested family rebate is proposed which would apply to all families, including sole parents, couples without children and couples with children, which is not exactly picket fence politics, I would have thought. This would replace the dependent spouse rebate and the sole parent rebate, and the Democrats are delighted with it. Again, we are the only party which has been getting up anywhere in politics in Australia and saying, `Let us get rid of the dependent spouse rebate and let us use it for child payments'. At the time we talked specifically about the family allowance. We would be interested to hear members of the Opposition, instead of all this hot air, saying what they think about this Australian Institute of Family Studies package.

The third point made in this package refers to changes to family allowances. The Institute states that rates for all children should be changed to $10 per week per child irrespective of the birth order of the child; that means testing of the family allowance should be abolished; and that the family allowance should be renamed the child tax allowance. I would be fascinated to hear Opposition speakers in this debate tell this Parliament-and I am quite sure they will not-what they think about a universal payment for children: getting child payments back as part of the tax system instead of part of the welfare system, which the introduction of income testing has done. I believe that that is an issue of major concern. Should our children be a matter for our welfare system or should they be incorporated in the tax system, as the Institute of Family Studies suggests?

The Institute goes on to suggest changes to the family allowance supplement-an increase of $1 per week for 13- to 15-year-old children-to bring it in line, and changes to the level of pensioner and beneficiary rebates. Those are the major components of that package, about which we have heard no comment as far as the Opposition is concerned, but about which we have had lots of hot air from the Opposition spokesperson trying to put the Government on the spot, the Government having said that it is addressing these issues and hopefully will bring us concrete comments soon.
I turn now to the Women's Tax Convention. It is important to note the introduction to the summary of the submissions. The Democrats would like to endorse this statement:

Women do have different perspectives on many of the issues under discussion. Their situation vis a vis the workforce and the social security system is often different from that of men. They are the bulk of low paid and part time workers, have high rates of dependency on social security transfer payments (pensions and benefits) and carry most of the responsibility for the daily care of children and other dependants.

Again, that is not exactly picket fence politics. The Democrats endorsed that statement at the beginning of the conference. There are a number of specific recommendations and again the Australian Democrats would be fascinated to hear from the Opposition on these recommendations. For instance, its recommendation on dependent spouse payments is very much along the lines of the recommendation of the Australian Institute of Family Studies. It is saying, `Let us get rid of that and let us turn it into a child payment', which again is something the Democrats have been saying for years. Another recommendation involves the children's services program. It is very important that all community service programs are stongly supported. How can they be in the context of a tax policy which is slowly emerging from the cocoon of the Opposition's policies? Clearly, its policy is likely to be based on the policy of the Business Council of Australia, which talks about higher interest rates and tax cuts--

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you know?

—Somebody had to pay for that glossy document, Senator. Obviously those people who are supporting the Liberal Party will have a great deal of input into its policies. We would be fascinated to see where those cuts are coming from. The latest suggestion from the Business Council of Australia is that there are $1 billion extra of cuts. How the Opposition will keep up those sorts of services I do not know.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to tax and wage changes. The real levels of the family allowance are to be indexed. Again, this has been Democrats policy right from the beginning. It is proposed here to increase the income test free area of pensions to $60 per week per individual and $30 per week per child. Again that is a proposal which the Democrats have been putting forward. Even before I made my maiden speech in this chamber, the first notice of motion that I put down called for a significant rise in the free income area. If we are ever to get rid of the poverty traps, we need incentives for pensioners and beneficiaries to get out of their poverty cycle, into paid employment, and off the welfare system, and to be independent. I will be fascinated to hear whether the Opposition finally supports that. The recommendations go on to stress:
The above does not preclude an integrated tax credit system for child support.
Again that is an Australian Institute of Family Studies proposal.

The Women's Tax Convention also had some strong words to say about and called for the abolition of the higher education contribution scheme. That is another measure on which the Australian Democrats stood alone in opposing in this chamber and out in the public arena. The convention complained about the inequities in superannuation tax concessions. My Party has had a policy of a universal national contributory superannuation scheme since its inception in 1977-12 years ago. We have been told that the time for that is past and that it is occupational superannuation for us all. Let us hope that it is for us all, including women, on an equal basis. The Democrats endorse that recommendation.

I have made some comments about public sector services, as has the Minister for Local Government. We cannot have social justice or, as Don Edgar would rather have us say, `a fair go for everyone', if we are to get into, as the Opposition has done, private education and private sector housing and cut back on public transport, communications and infrastructure and the public media. None of that can lead to a fair go for everyone. If we are to cut spending we will cut public services. We hear lots of questions being asked of the Government by the Opposition, but we see no policies from the Opposition. We have had a barrage of questions, but we want to know what is the Opposition's attitude both to the proposals of the Institute of Family Studies and to the tax convention.

I understand that the Women's Tax Convention proposals will be put to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on International Women's Day on Wednesday. I suggest that the organisers press the Opposition equally as hard. They must face the fact that this is an election year and I think they should be putting the Opposition equally on the spot as they are the Government. After all, most of the time here we have Tweedledum and Tweedledee or, as somebody once put it, Tweedledum and Tweedle-even-dumber. I think the Women's Tax Convention should apply pressure across the board, bearing in mind my comments about our support for those issues.

The Opposition has not had a great deal to say about tax equity. We are talking here about restructuring the tax system-a motion put up by a party which opposes the removal of the exemption of the gold industry from normal company tax. The Opposition calls it a gold tax, et cetera, but does not seem too perturbed that the top 200 companies are only paying 28c in the dollar when the level was 49c; and the Opposition has not opposed, as the Democrats did, the reduction of company tax to 39c, while individuals are still waiting for their tax cuts. Individuals are paying the foreign debt, which is largely there through the private sector. We are also paying through cuts to government services as this Government has cut back its funding, particularly through the States. These are generated largely by the private sector, that same private sector that this Opposition continually supports and shelters. There are challenges from the Democrats to the Opposition, most particularly on this issue of whether it will support the legislation introduced by Senator Haines last week on the issue of savings and housing. We hear all kinds of noises, but it appears that the only measures that the Opposition would be interested in would be those which, once again, would support high income people.

We have had deregulation. We are looking at the big picture. We have been asked to do this from people on both sides of the chamber. The Opposition does not say anything. Some measures have been taken by the Government, but none of them goes far enough. Certainly we need to restructure. The Democrats suggest that we need some pretty radical thinking. I commend to the Senate, and I foreshadow, further debate from the Democrats on this issue of national income support which would get the whole question of payments to support all individuals, including families, out of the welfare area and into removing the need for pensions and benefits-a system which will get over the problems of social welfare, industrial relations, employment and taxation which constitute the mess that we have got ourselves into today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the matter of urgency moved by Senator Hill, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the government to restructure the tax system to remove the bias against families with dependants and to tackle the issues raised in the Institute of Family Studies report which documents the sharp fall in real disposable income suffered by most families under six years of hard Labor, a report which the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women failed to address when asked about it in the Senate on Friday.

The National Agenda for Women, which was released in March last year and which no doubt honourable senators are familiar with, indicates in the early stages of the booklet that the Government believes that a government's economic policies are the best way to ensure a bright and secure future for all Australians. That is a very sensible statement. It is a sensible acknowledgment that we can have all the conferences, all the workshops and all the glossy leaflets we like. We have heard from Senator Hill details of the conferences that this Government has organised relating to matters that are of concern to women. We have heard about the workshops and the glossy leaflets. But, of course, what the statement in the National Agenda for Women tells us, when it says that the economy is the best way to provide a bright and secure future for all Australians, is that we can have all the circuses we like and they will remain circuses unless we do something with what we are told at the conferences and with what we learn from the workshops. People, in the end, expect some results from this sort of effort and they have not been forthcoming.

I know from Senator Powell's contribution that she wants to know what solutions the Opposition has to offer. She will learn the details of our taxation and economic policies in due course. She will not learn the details of them in sufficient time for this Labor Government to do what it normally does when the Opposition releases its policies, that is, snitch them a few months later, rename them as something else and simply take our good ideas. We are not offended by that; we are complimented that the Government sees the errors of its ways and follows the policies that we release.

I am, in a sense, embarrassed to be participating in this debate today. I find it embarrassing that the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Reynolds), the woman in government who is meant to be representing the women of Australia and putting our views, cannot seem to get to where the real action is, namely, the hard economic issues. She is not even interested in this debate. She has had her say and she is off, probably, having a cup of tea. It is a pity that she is not here to contribute to the debate over and above her own speech, by way of interjection, follow-up or whatever.

If Cabinet is a sort of football field, if that is how government works, the guys are all in there grabbing the ball for their department. But what is Senator Reynolds doing? She is carrying the drinks. That is all she is doing in the hard political game in terms of representing women. The ball is going past and she is not catching it on my behalf, on behalf of single income families, on behalf of dual income families or on behalf of part time workers. She has demonstrated quite clearly an incapacity to get into the hard economic issues. The National Agenda for Women produced by the Government clearly acknowledges that that is where the action is for all Australians. Women deserve better and, in that sense, I am embarrassed.

My colleague Senator Hill asked why women are not prepared to support Bob Hawke. I have a few answers to that question. Some of them might have taken the suggestion I offered last year and read Blanche d'Alpuget's biography of Bob Hawke. That would give an insight into the man. I suggest to those who have not read it that it may change a few views. Then again I have another suggestion: perhaps some women have been watching the national television news and have heard the Prime Minister cursing, taking, as I understand it, the Lord's name in vain, because he misses a golf shot. He did this in front of the national news services. I do not care what he does in his private life or at the Lodge. But, quite frankly, I do not think that sort of standard on national television is acceptable from a Prime Minister. I do not care at all what he does in his private life.

Then again some women may have been listening to the AM program and heard the Prime Minister tell a reporter, in what I understand is a polite version of it, where to get off. I can tell honourable senators that Australian women regard that as an unacceptable standard for a Prime Minister. We would laugh hysterically if we heard Maggie Thatcher speaking that way. We would think that she had gone off her head and deserved to be locked up. One would not hear President Bush or President Gorbachev speaking that way. But that is how we hear this Prime Minister speaking. Women are not impressed with it. They expect a better standard.

Women expect something to be delivered from a Prime Minister who promises so much. They are fed up with the circuses, the conferences and the offers to listen. They now want action on what has been said. Women have heard all the promises. The most current one in vogue to talk about is the promise with respect to child poverty in 1990. There are others that we would do well to remember, namely, the promise of 75,000 Australian trainees per annum in the bicentennial year. That little promise went by the board. We had up to 15,000 in that year, if we were lucky. It is my assessment that 17,000 Australian trainees would have been the cumulative total for the entire program from 1985. But we had the Prime Minister promising, `Don't you worry, men and women'-or boys and girls, if one wants to put it that way because it was particularly for young Australians-`my Government understands your problems and that you need training. It is a very important issue for women. You will have 75,000 traineeships available per annum by the bicentennial year'. What has come of it? Nothing. It puts the worth of the Prime Minister's promises at approximately 10c in the dollar or less. It is very important that the Government immediately address the issues raised in the report by the Institute of Family Studies entitled Families and Taxation in 1989.

I indicated to honourable senators earlier that I was somewhat embarrassed at the Minister's incapacity to reply. She is apparently not conversant with the report and apparently can only read from the documents provided by other Ministers. She says that we do not understand the distribution of ministerial responsibilities. She says that she is not responsible for the Institute of Family Studies and that she cannot be expected to be across this report. Apparently, we should not mind the fact that it affects most women in this country. It affects all the single parent families in desperate situations now, all the dual income families and all the single income families. But the Minister does not have to worry about that as it is not her ministerial responsibility; that is her view.

I wonder whether she has the same view when putting forward a discussion, for example, on equal employment opportunity. Does she say, `This is not my problem; this comes under the portfolio of the Minister for Industrial Relations.' Of course she does not, because she has some capacity to throw a few words around with respect to equal employment opportunity. She is happy to have a go. Does she say with respect to X-rated videos that it is not her responsibility; it is the Attorney-General's responsibility? No, she does not. Does she say with respect to child-care that she is not expected to be across that as that is a function of the Department of Community Services and Health? No, she does not. She has a go at getting across that because it is a matter that she has some understanding of and is conversant with. Does she say with respect to access to education that it is not her problem and that she will leave that up to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training? No, she does not, because she knows how important access to education is to women.

Similarly with training, she does not leave it up to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. She knows that she is expected to be across these sorts of issues, and similarly with respect to access to health. One asks why, when one comes to the section of government activity which the Government itself admits is the core way to ensure a bright and secure future to all Australians, namely, the economy, the Minister ducks out and says that it is not her responsibility and that we should speak to someone else.

Perhaps we should, at this stage, turn our minds to why we need to address the problem of the taxation structure for families with dependent children. It is obvious, in the first instance, that a simple, glib answer is that families are our future. But, of course, in order to support Senator Hill's motion we have to show that families are under stress and that some restructuring needs to be done. I remind honourable senators who are present or listening of seven or eight reasons why families are now under stress. I am not talking now about just the single income, dual parent family with two happy children. I am talking about sole parents, single income families, dual income families where people work full time or part time-all families with dependent children.

Let us listen to some of the reasons why these families are under stress under this Government. When we left government in March 1983 the home loan interest rate was 12.5 per cent. It is now 15.5 per cent. That has to impact on families. Another cause of stress is bankruptcy. It is a mistake to think of people who go bankrupt as being isolated businessmen. They probably have families. Bankruptcy has serious consequences for their families. The average in the Fraser years was 4,717. The average in the years of this Prime Minister has gone up to 7,138. Living standards have definitely fallen under this Government. The marginal tax rate for an average income earner in March 1983 was 30c in the dollar. It has now shifted up to 40c in the dollar. In March 1983, under the last Liberal-National Government, the average monthly home loan repayment was $350. It is now $778. If someone does not understand how that impacts upon families with dependent children, let me tell them that that repayment as a percentage of income has skyrocketed from just a little over 19 per cent to 30 per cent under this Government, and that makes it difficult for families.

If the Government does not want to hear about people who want to buy a house-those who are lucky enough to have a job and be able to have a go at it under this Government-it should look at public housing waiting lists. In December 1982, there were 110,000 people on public housing waiting lists. Under this Government, in December 1988 there were 160,000. The waiting period for public housing for people who do not have the opportunity to buy their own home is deplorable.

Let us look at a sixth factor. Let us look at family allowances, which have been frozen by Labor, and the dependent spouse rebate. Under this Government there has been a fall of 37 per cent in real terms for a family with children. If that does not tell us why this matter is vitally important for families and why the Minister should be across it-families include women and children-let us look at a couple more. Let us look at unemployment. I know that the Government says it has created, or the economy has generated, a number of additional jobs, but that is not the only way of looking at the matter. Under the Fraser Government the average monthly unemployment level was 403,000. It is now 627,000. That means there are individuals out of jobs who therefore have trouble supporting their families.

The average monthly youth unemployment level under the Hawke Government is 130,000. Under Fraser it was 115,000. That was not good, but nonetheless the figure was lower. Under the Hawke Government the average monthly youth unemployment rate is 23 per cent. Under Fraser it was 18.6 per cent. That tells us how many families have young people still dependent on them, people who cannot get a job but who want a job-young Australians, both men and women, who were promised traineeships by the Prime Minister. In the bicentennial year they were promised 75,000 traineeships per annum. What has been delivered? Not very much at all. So it is with real regret that we see that the Minister simply cannot address the hard economic issues. I remind the Minister of an article in the Age newspaper to which I have drawn her attention previously called `Orange among the mandarins'. The article is about the Office of the Status of Women and is written by Eva Cox, a noted Sydney social policy consultant. She said:
Under Malcolm Fraser, there was a powerful National Women's Advisory Council which spoke about against government decisions and represented its constituency.
She went on to say:
Some women are asking whether the resources going into the National Women's Consultative Council should be diverted to an independent peak group which could speak out.

That is a relevant point because the Minister says that the National Women's Consultative Council is independent. Yet, when she quoted a letter from her chairman, she said, `My chairman'-her Council; appointed by her. I ask the National Women's Consultative Council to think very seriously about the contribution it makes and to show its independence publicly because, as Eva Cox said, if the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women continues `to be seen as marginal and irrelevant to the main issues'-we are talking about the economy and tax-the advantage that Labor has gained with women voters `may be whittled away'. How right she was. If the Minister does not want to play ball, let her get out of the park. Perhaps she should give Senator Crowley-who is not in the chamber-a go. Perhaps Jeannette McHugh or Wendy Fatin in the lower House would like a go. I want someone to do for women something other than carry the drinks. I want someone to go into Cabinet and argue very hard for me. The Minister is incapable of doing that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that we should put the record straight on a matter on which Senator Vanstone commented on several occasions. It is so long since the coalition has been in government that it has completely forgotten what ministerial responsibilities can be. Quite apart from all the other misconstruction that Senator Vanstone put on the position of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Reynolds) this afternoon, I make it quite clear that at the moment the Minister is having a meeting with the Australian Pensioners Federation. She is discussing with the Australian Pensioners Federation a submission on the needs of older women, focusing particularly on the solid economic issues which concern women in their mature years. She is probably having a great deal more fruitful time than she could possibly have in this chamber. She would not learn very much this afternoon from the coalition, which has brought forward a matter of urgency which purported to be about a report produced by the Institute of Family Studies (IFS).

SPEECH.PARA: The report is quite extensive and very substantial. Released on Thursday of last week, it is entitled `AFIT Bulletin No. 5', has 56 pages, and comprises solid, mostly economic, theory. The Institute's paper expressly endorses the Government's strategy of giving priority to low income families through the family allowance supplement and rejects the Opposition's policy of income splitting. There is an interesting point. We have not heard much about income splitting from the Opposition this afternoon. It has been very vocal about it on a number of occasions over the last few years and dredges it up just about every time we come up to an election. That was one of the matters discussed quite thoroughly at the Women's Tax Convention on Saturday. If Senator Vanstone had been there she would have heard how thoroughly the women there understand that it would be an extremely regressive way of approaching any sort of restructuring of the income tax system. We have heard nothing from the Opposition this afternoon about what might be a way of restructuring the income tax system. All that we have to go on is what is we have heard in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it a pity the Minister did not stay and listen?

—Maybe when Senator Newman's contribution arrives we will get a little more enlightenment. Those listening to this debate and those who get around to reading it in Hansard at some future time would probably like to know the thrust of the report on tax that has just been produced by the Institute of Family Studies. I will summarise very briefly the main points that it makes. It concludes that the Government's strategy of giving priority to low income families is the way we should go. It concludes that tax cuts are justified for all taxpayers but should be targeted to middle income families, particularly those with children, and to low income single people who have not benefited from the family allowance supplement. The report places emphasises on increasing concessions to families. That point was made extremely strongly by the women at the meeting on Saturday.

SPEECH.PARA: The report also advocates abolishing the dependent spouse rebate, which is seen as a rather ineffectual way of redistributing resources to families with dependent children, and suggests that the DSR be replaced with a family rebate, income tested on family income. The IFS also supports a universal family allowance and gives support to the notion that all family allowance payments should be the same rather than being graded in relation to the place in the family of each child.

The Institute advocates the lowering of marginal tax rates up to $45,000. The piece of fiction entitled Future Directions advocates `a flatter tax system with two steps'-very fair, I must say!-`in order to provide incentive to people to work harder and to exercise enterprise and initiative'. That is what the coalition, or Liberal Party at least, seems to be advocating. However, the Institute of Family Studies suggests an extra step so that at $5,000 there would be a percentage rate of 22; at $13,500, 29; at $20,000, 35; at $35,000, 40; and at $45,000, 49. That is probably the first bit of hard factual data to go into this debate this afternoon about the issue that we are supposed to be dealing with but which, having been taken off in all sorts of highways and byways, we have hardly got to. The Institute of Family Studies suggests that the new family rebate, of which I spoke before, should be $16,000; that there should be a family allowance at a flat rate of $10 per child per week; and that an addition of $1 per week be made to the family allowance supplement. It also advocates an increase in the pensioner benefit rebate. So far so good; that is the taxation side of it.

As has been stated here this afternoon, there is no doubt in anybody's mind that the Government's position, that the good management of the economy is the best way of raising the incomes and standard of living of the population, is by far the most sensible and effective way to go. Over the six years we have been in government the work force participation rate has risen to 63 per cent, the highest in Australian history. The women's participation rate is over 50 per cent. Forty per cent of women are in the work force. The M-curve is flattening out, which means that women are leaving the work force to have children at a later age and for shorter periods. The important point about this set of figures is that the number of households in Australia where both spouses are employed has risen from 46 per cent in 1984-85 to 55 per cent in 1988-89. This means that in a great many more households there is considerable more disposable income. So, when one is looking at tax rates, one may have a skewed view of exactly how much disposable income is available.

There are many more ways of increasing disposable income than putting it in a person's pay-packet, or of reducing it as the result of income taxation. Already mention has been made this afternoon of the $67 a week on average which goes to low income families with two children who are getting the benefit of Medicare, Austudy and superannuation. Two other measures we have undertaken and which are making a great deal of difference to the average income and well-being of low income families are the family allowance supplement and the child support scheme. This Government had the courage and the integrity to introduce the family allowance supplement. In 1987 the entire financial community and the coalition were baying for drastic cuts in public spending. We were able to see that we had to make a genuine funding allocation to enhance the living standards of the lowest income families with dependent children. As a result we introduced the family allowance supplement, which has made an enormous difference to the well-being of 141,000 Australian families, with something like 300,000 children. An average of $40 a week goes to those families.

Measures of this nature in the long run are transfers of income from taxation into the purses of women and keep individual families going. Measures of this nature are of crucial importance. A large number of families have already been assisted by the child support scheme, introduced on 1 August last year. By 25 February, 13,178 cases had been registered with the Child Support Agency out of a total of 17,168 applications. The number of all Department of Social Security pensioners receiving maintenance increased from 66,455 in June 1988 to 83,149 in February 1989. This is highly significant. These pensioners maintenance has increased, not through the Child Support Agency or by their having been dealt with directly by the Government, but because as a result of our introducing this scheme maintenance orders are being increased to a much more realistic level. Whereas previously custodial parents were expected to feed, clothe, shelter and educate their children on something like $25 a week, they are now being given much more realistic maintenance orders. The average rate of maintenance received by sole parent pensioners increased between June and February from $36 a week to $49 a week-a not inconsiderable improvement. Many of these families are amongst the most poverty stricken in the community.

The Government believes that the document put out by the Institute of Family Studies is a very useful analysis of the effects of the tax transfer system on hypothetical average weekly earning couples. The Institute of Family Studies is a highly respected organisation. It has not always been shown a great deal of respect by the coalition. If I recall correctly, Mr Howard has made some rather scathing remarks in the past about the Institute of Family Studies, but suddenly he is seeing it as a useful tool. I am glad that he has seen the light.

The Institute of Family Studies document contains a considerable amount of data. It presents a number of options. I have given merely an overall summary of the measures the Institute advocates, which in many cases are along the same lines as the way in which the Government has been thinking for a long time. They are along the same lines as the way in which the women who met on Saturday have been thinking for a long time. They are along the same lines as we have been moving over the years. In 1987, the Economic Planning Advisory Council did a study of exactly how much had been added to average incomes as a result of the social wage. That was before the introduction of the family allowance supplement and the Child Support Agency. Those two very significant measures which have been taken since then would have increased the 1986-87 figure of 5 per cent.

I have not even mentioned the fact that we have introduced a rental subsidy for people who rent privately and increased the disabled child allowance to $112 a month, a much more substantial amount than it was previously, which helps to meet the extra needs that we know make such a big difference to the costs of families with disabled children. It is absolutely clear that the Opposition is still totally bereft of ideas for taxation reconstruction. I have here an extract from the Future Directions document, which Senator Vanstone tells us is not a policy document. We must assume that it is fiction, recreation or whatever.

I note with a great deal of interest that the Opposition has decided that it would not introduce a broad-based consumption tax in its first term. Can we believe that? —I raise a point of order. I took great care to put the record straight on that particular issue. I would ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, not to allow Senator Newman to go on maligning--
