SPEECH.PARA: We have just heard a diatribe from Senator Giles about women working and incomes coming into the families. Like Senator Crowley, who gave us the benefit of her lack of understanding one night last week in a debate when she proudly said that 50 per cent of Australian women were out working, Senator Giles does not understand that so many of these women are economic conscripts; there is no other way to describe it. They are working in order to bring some income into the family; but increasingly, that income is decreasing in value and the bread and the cheese are getting more and more expensive every week. Any housewife not sitting in the Senate pretending to know the cost of living and pretending to know why these women are working would understand exactly what is happening to the economy and this Government's mismanagement of it.

In my contribution to this important debate, I intend to highlight the way in which the Government has treated defence families because they are a group which, because of their special circumstances, give a special benchmark against which we can test the Government's real credentials for demonstrating concern for families. If the Minister for Local Government had not left the conference hall at morning tea, she would have heard the representative from the national board of the National Council of Women speak on the problems of service families and other transient families, which in many ways are much worse than those being suffered by families in the suburbs. Service families not only reflect the serious consequences of government policy which affect all Australian families but also show how a captive group can be even more affected by a government which simply does not care. Clearly there is in the tax system a bias against families. In the same way as the report of the Institute of Family Studies has done, I intend to document the fall in real disposable income and the standard of living of our defence families. There are 38,500 Defence Force personnel who are married and of these a huge proportion have two children. It is this family unit which has been used many times in the report Families and Tax in 1989 to demonstrate how badly families are being attacked by this Government.

As a generality, in 1976-77 a two-children family with a taxpayer on average weekly earnings received a 46 per cent tax reduction compared with a single person. In 1988-89 this figure had dropped to 26 per cent. In the defence forces a number of other issues come into play which make this basic reduction in family living standards even worse. I intend to demonstrate this proposition by giving a number of examples from the following areas: taxation, education, removals, housing, service allowance and so on.

Let me tell honourable senators about tax changes. The Government has introduced changes in taxation provisions that have severely reduced the real level of income of servicemen and their families. I draw attention to the uniform maintenance allowance. Until two weeks ago servicemen were provided with a uniform allowance which was tax free. It was designed to replace items of compulsory uniform, as well as maintenance, et cetera. On 21 February the Government advised its servicemen that this allowance would now have to be substantiated.

Previously the allowance had always been treated as an `in-out' allowance where it was assumed that it would be expended totally for the purposes for which it was paid. Therefore, a large proportion of servicemen have not kept records of how that money has been spent. They will be unable to substantiate their claims this financial year and they may well suffer penalties at the hands of the Taxation Commissioner as a result. This, of course, means that their allowance for replacement of compulsory uniforms will be taxed this financial year, which is another blow to the family budget.

Let me draw attention to the Medicare levy and the service family. As I think most people would understand, but perhaps the Labor Party does not approve, servicemen are provided with free medical care because of their service and they are not subject to a Medicare levy for themselves. Their families are not provided with free medical care and so a serviceman pays half a medicare levy when he has a dependent spouse. Incredible as it may seem, when a spouse works and pays her own Medicare levy, this provision does not change. So the serviceman still has to pay 50 per cent of a Medicare levy even though his wife is paying for her own and he is entitled to free care. This is a direct additional cost to the family income which cannot be substantiated either in logic or in equity. It has been described by Dr Paul Gerber of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as being completely unsupportable. Yet the Government has refused to change the requirement. It is yet another sneaky, illogical impost to grab even more revenue. Again, it is directly at the expense of the family. As the report of the Institute of Family Studies points our, during recent years there has been a large increase in the number of spouses who have gone out to work, in addition to the prime breadwinner, in order to make ends meet. I referred to that earlier. Service families are particularly disadvantaged because they have an inability to find those second jobs because of their constant posting routine. They are constantly met with opposition from local employers who give jobs to the locals because they know that the service spouses will be moving on.

One way service spouses can get some additional income into the family is to join the Reserve. Reserve pay is meant to be non-taxable. But, as usual with this Government, there is a catch. Let us take the example of a wife who has a position in the Reserve. Her pay is not taxable but when her husband is confronted with his tax return he finds he cannot claim her as a dependant because the level of dependency depends on all her sources of income, which are meant to be tax free. He loses the concession and once more it is the family which suffers to the tune of probably $1 in each $4 of additional earnings made by the wife through her Reserve service. Everywhere these families turn there is some new tax bite upon them.

Let me draw attention to the education allowance and the drop in living standards in that area. The Defence Force has recognised that an education allowance should be paid to defence families to assist in defraying costs incurred by soldiers who make arrangements for their children's secondary education to see that they do not suffer serious interference if the father is posted away. That sounds fair enough-a proper provision to ensure families are fairly treated. But the reality is quite different. In many ways this allowance exists in name only. In the last school year, out of the 34,000 service families with children only 82 members of the Defence Force were paid this allowance in respect of 93 children. The conditions are too stringent and complicated. There is a whole maze of restrictions and regulations which makes it almost impossible to obtain. Once again, the Government seems hell bent on making family life difficult for members of the defence forces.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you would be well aware of the fact that servicemen are being required to move constantly, and even more so in recent times because of the great losses from the defence forces and people being posted to fill the gaps. The question of removals becomes an extremely important issue. Soldiers are provided with free removals and some allowances that are designed to reduce the costs to them and to their families. But once again, the gap between what is needed and what is given is very large. Let me refer to a letter I received from the wife of a Royal Australian Air Force serviceman who documented in detail the removal expense which applied to a family of two children and two adults during their move from Canberra to Adelaide. These figures take into account the net effects of allowances which are received. The bill from the old locality to meet costs such as cleaning materials, telephone calls, transfer insurance and memberships which were not transferable or refundable totalled $503. At the new locality, costs for cleaning, telephone calls, garden items, schools uniforms, drivers licences, school fees, telephone connection fees, et cetera, amounted to $1,543. That is a total of over $2,000, of which they received $680. In other words, the family was expected to fork out over $1,400 for the privilege of taking up a new posting to defend this country, once again another strike against the standard of living of that family unit. One must remember that in six months' time that family may well be told that it will have to pack up and move to Perth, Darwin or Cairns. It could happen twice in a year, and certainly to many families it is happening once a year. I see Senator Collins is present; he would know the problems of such families who go in and out of Darwin.

Defence salaries are supplemented by a range of allowances to compensate for disabilities or exceptional circumstances. The most significant of these is the service allowance. In September this year the allowance was $4,002 a year. In 1987 the Services were seeking an allowance of a minimum of $7,715, mainly because members were on average working about 52.5 hours a week, were not being compensated, and of course received no penalty rates. These long, unrewarded hours clearly have a significant effect on the quality of family life. One wife gave the following evidence to the Cross subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade:

It is alright to say we are compensated by the time off, but mostly that has to be taken at the Air Force's convenience, and not when it is most beneficial to us. Time off does not pay the bills and it is no good having time off when you've got no money to do anything anyway.

Some of the personnel are now working 58 hours and up to 72 hours a week, as has been documented by the forces, because there is not enough manpower left to do the job which this Government requires of them. If ever there is an example of a total lack of understanding of and sympathy for the plight of servicemen and their families, this must be it. The Government trades on their commitment to work whatever hours are required, and the families are expected to put up with it.

There are problems concerned with the cost of housing. I do not have time to go into it, but assistance is given in regard to rentals. When personnel are sent to capital cities there are difficulties because, as we all know, rentals have been skyrocketing. Yet the Government does not review the ceilings on allowances. As at November last year, for Adelaide the allowances were last reviewed in August 1986, for Brisbane in July 1987, for Melbourne in August 1986, and for Sydney in November 1987. No wonder service families are finding that they cannot afford to go to these areas. Many families are being separated while the husbands go ahead and the families stay behind somewhere cheaper where they have a house they can afford. I have no opportunity to discuss the subject of child care, but we know that the standard of living of service families has been very much reduced because of their inability to obtain access to child care. Therefore, there is difficulty in bringing a second income to the family. This affects their standard of living. This Government has an employer scheme-a scheme to give employers in private industry assistance with child-care schemes. Servicemen and their families are not eligible for the subsidies under that scheme, and yet the Defence Department is a major employer.

The Families and Tax report has shown how families and their standard of living have been attacked. On top of these revelations, I have demonstrated how families are disadvantaged in the Defence Force. It is a stark recital of how the standards of the family unit are being lowered, making it more difficult to educate, clothe, feed and look after children-making it more difficult even to hold a marriage together. All Australian families are $58 a week worse off since this Government came to office. One might have thought that the Government would have taken more responsibility for the families of the servicemen who defend our standard of living, but that is not the case. Such families are even worse off than most families, largely as a result of a lack of government support or of government action. The Government stands condemned for its treatment of all Australian families, and in particular Defence Force families.

RESOLUTIONS OF THE WOMEN'S TAX CONVENTION 4 MARCH 1989-PARLIAMENT HOUSE CANBERRA
The Women's Tax Convention resolved:
Child Allowance or credit

(1) that the cost of children be given greater financial recognition in the tax-social security transfer system and that this entitlement to a child allowance or credit be indexed and paid to the primary care giver, outside any considerations of income;
Payments for children
(2) that, in recognition of the contribution of children as a future resource of the community, a system of payments for children be instituted. Such a payment should:
recognise that the costs of children should be shared between the community and the parent(s)
be a standardised amount paid universally for each child (regardless of the marital or workforce status of the carer) as compensation for the costs of children;
be paid to the primary care-giver;
be recognised in the tax system as a tax equity measure;
be indexed;
be paid at an adequate level (which will ensure an increase to the present level of child payment);
ensure affordable and good quality child care.
Increased indexed and universal family allowance and pensioner earnings
(3) that the forthcoming tax-wage changes for women should in the immediate future include:
increasing to 1976 real level Family Allowances (tax credits) and for these to be indexed from now on, restoring universality;
increasing the income test free area of pension to $60 per week per individual and $30 per week per child.
The above does not preclude an integrated tax credit system for child support.
Removal of workforce disincentives

(4) that a priority of government should be the removal of workforce disincentives brought about by the interaction of the social security and taxation systems which result in poverty traps that particularly disadvantage sole parents and potential second income earners moving back into the workforce.
Replacement of Dependent Spouse Payments
(5) that present payments for dependent spouses be replaced by a combination of direct cash payments for children and low-income families.
Priority for low income earners in tax changes

(6) that priority in the forthcoming tax changes be given to low-income earners, of whom the majority are women This will necessitate such changes as the closing of tax loopholes and a fairer distribution of the tax burden to all sectors of the community.
Wage increases for low income workers

(7) that in wage/tax trade off discussions and subsequent policy developments high priority be given to raising the wages of low income workers through supplementary payments and other measures. Both the ACTU and the Government are urged to support wage increases for low-income earners, the majority of whom are women.
Maintain/Extend Public Sector Services

(8) that the provision of services from tax revenue is critical to providing an equitable society and thus states that any forthcoming tax changes should ensure that we can maintain and extend the role of the public sector in providing services.
Other Issues
Expansion of Children's Services Program

(9) that the Children's Services Program be expanded as a key component of the economic infrastructure, that it be adequately funded to ensure high-quality and affordable child care, and that the present structure of operational grants and subsidies be maintained and expanded, and that these be indexed from now on.
Superannuation Tax Concessions
(10) that tax concessions for superannuation contributors discriminate against women most of whose workforce participation is irregular and low paid. ``Retirement'' is a gender-based concept.
Abolition of Higher Education Contribution Scheme

(11) that this Convention views with concern the adverse effects of H.E.C.S. (Higher Education Contribution Scheme) on women and that we urge the Government to re-establish education as a priority and abolish this tax as it, among other things, disadvantages women.
National Accounts/Unpaid Work
(12) that women's unpaid work in the home be fully recognised in the national accounts.
Concern re: Broader Issues

(13) that while the convention has not provided resolutions on issues such as assets, provisional sales or consumption taxes it is not an indication of women's lack of concern about the broader issues.
Issues for further examination
(14) that the following areas require further examination before any proposals can be put forward:
income equalisation;
provisional tax;
value of unpaid work;
sales tax;
raising the tax free threshold by $1500 and indexing that threshold thereafter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) relating to Namibia and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
STATEMENT TO PARLIAMENT BY THE LEADER OF THE GOVERNMENT IN THE SENATE ON NAMIBIA
6 MARCH 1989

I seek leave to report to the Senate on recent events in Namibia and Australia's role in assisting the implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 435 of 1978, providing for the withdrawal of South African military forces from Namibia and the holding of elections under UN supervision and control.

As announced by the Ministers for Defence and Foreign Affairs and Trade on 2 March 1989, a contingent of three hundred Australian engineers will leave shortly for Namibia. They will form part of a United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Namibia that will help bring independence to Namibia after more than one hundred years of rule by foreign powers. The settlement of the long and complex issue of Namibian independence is an important international event. It is an event in which Australia has played, and will continue to play, a substantial part.

During the Prime Minister's recent visit to India, he noted that there had been much talk during the 1970s and early 1980s about an arc of instability stretching from southern Africa, through the Persian Gulf, through Afghanistan and South Asia and on to Indochina. We see now, if not an arc of peace, than at least an arc of peace-making. It is a process, facilitated by an improvement in superpower relations and aided by the constructive role of the United Nations, that is finally bringing the treasured goal of independence within sight of the people of Namibia. The Government recognises that the problems in southern Africa constitute one of the major challenges facing the international community. We have sought, through the United Nations, the Commonwealth and our own diplomatic links with countries in the region, to find peaceful solutions to the complex set of problem that trouble that region.

In recent times, there has been little cause for optimism in southern Africa. The offensive doctrine of apartheid remains entrenched in South Africa's social, political and economic life. Civil wars with drastic human consequences continue in Mozambique and Angola. The Front Line States of southern Africa-including fellow Commonwealth members such as Botswana, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe-continue to be vulnerable to economic and military destabilisation. The question of Namibia, in many ways, encapsulated a number of these problems. The fact that Namibia is now on the way to independence demonstrates that concerted international action, the determination of the region, and the goodwill of individual players can combine to bring solutions to longstanding problems in the region. For southern Africa torn by attrition, deprivation and tragedy, recent moves on Namibia offer a glimmer of hope. Namibia has been the international community for 70 Years. South Africa was appointed mandatary over the former German colony of South West Africa by the Treaty of Versailles in 1919, in circumstances similar to Australia's own mandate over Papua New Guinea. This mandate was confirmed by the League of Nations.

After the Second World War, the League of Nations was superseded by the United Nations, and the mandate system by the trusteeship system. Alone of the former mandatary powers, South Africa refused to submit a trusteeship agreement for South West Africa, or Namibia, as it is now known. In 1966, the UN General Assembly resolved that South Africa's role in Namibia should be terminated, and that the responsibility for the territory should be assumed by a UN-appointed Council for Namibia. Despite these decisions, South Africa continued to govern Namibia against the wishes of the United Nations, and claimed sovereignty over it in the face of widespread international condemnation.

South African rule has been opposed from within Namibia since 1957 by the South West African People's Organisation, SWAPO. SWAPO commenced an armed struggle in 1966, and was supported in this by Namibia's neighbour to the north, Angola, when it achieved independence in 1975.

South Africa responded by supporting an insurgency against the Government of Angola, and by direct attacks against Angolan Government forces inside Angola. Angola sought Cuban involvement and as many as 50,000 Cuban troops have been deployed there at any one time. This involvement, with substantial Soviet backing, became a significant source of East-West tension.

It has taken years to begin to untangle this mess. In 1978 the UN agreed on a plan for a settlement contained in UN Security Council Resolution 435, but intransigence on all sides prevented that plan from being implemented. Then last year, in the context of reduced East-West tensions, the log-jam started to break up. South Africa agreed to withdraw its forces and to allow Namibia its independence, while Angola agreed to the withdrawal of Cuban forces and the removal of African National Congress camps from its territory. The signing of the Brazzaville Protocol on 22 December last year by South Africa, Cuba and Angola has at last formalised the acceptance by South Africa of the 1978 UN settlement plan.

Last month the UN Security Council agreed that the transition to independence for Namibia would begin on 1 April 1989. Over the 12 months from that date the UN will monitor the withdrawal of foreign forces, oversee the drafting and adoption of a Constitution, and supervise the installation of a new Government after general elections.

A vital element in this plan is the United Nations Transition Assistance Group, UNTAG. It will monitor the ceasefire and troop withdrawals, supervise elections, and support the maintenance of law and order in Namibia until the new government of independent Namibia is ready to take over.

The scale of these tasks is reflected in the size of the force. UNTAG will have civilian, police and military elements. The military element will consist initially of 4,650 personnel including three infantry battalions, with scope for expansion to 7,500 should the circumstances demand.

Australia is providing the engineering component of UNTAG. Our contingent of 23 officers and 277 other ranks will provide engineering and construction support to the UN effort. Such support will be sorely needed. Namibia is a large, arid, sparsely-populated and underdeveloped country which has been a war zone for many years. Our engineers will build roads, bridges, airstrips and camps for UNTAG. They will have the very serious task of clearing mines which have been laid by the various contending forces along the border between Angola and Namibia.

This is of course not the first time Australian personnel have been involved with a peacekeeping force in Africa; we participated in the Commonwealth force that monitored Zimbabwe's transition to independence in 1980. In that process, as in others before and since, Australian defence forces played a constructive role in what can be a difficult and sometimes dangerous process.

Members of the Australian contingent will serve in Namibia for tours of six months, after which they will be replaced by a fresh contingent from Australia. The UN plans to complete Namibia's transition to independence within a year, but delays in this complex process are possible, and we may be called upon to stay longer than a year.

The bulk of the Australian contingent will be based at Grootfontein in the north of Namibia, near the border with Angola. Elements of the contingent could be required to deploy into neighbouring countries to support UNTAG operations there.

This is a very large and important commitment for Australia, comprising almost half of the Army's construction engineering capability. Careful planning, including the use of Reservists, has been required to ensure that high-priority engineering tasks closer to home can still be performed.

I am pleased to say that it has been possible to minimise the impact of the deployment on support of the operational deployment force, exercise Kangaroo 89, and the defence cooperation program in the South Pacific, where our engineers build wharves, airstrips and other essential infrastructure.

It has to be understood that the political and military situation in the border region where the bulk of our men will be deployed will remain uncertain and outbreaks of fighting cannot be ruled out. Members of the Australian contingent will travel often on minor and remote roads. They will be responsible for the dangerous work of clearing mines throughout the country. Threats are also posed by disease and the harsh environment.
Against these dangers should be set the fact that our service personnel are experts in their profession; they are well trained and will be armed for self-defence.

I can assure honourable senators that the safety of the Australian contingent is uppermost in the Government's mind. To ensure that we are kept fully informed of developments that may affect the well-being of the Australian contingent, the Government has decided to establish a temporary Australian Liaison Office in the Namibian capital of Windhoek for the duration of the 12 month independence process. The Office will provide the Government with first hand reporting on political and military developments in the territory, during what at times is likely to be a difficult process. The Office will be headed by an experienced diplomat with many years background in African affairs.

The Government has also ensured that members of the Australian contingent be adequately compensated for the hardships and dangers they will face through a comprehensive and generous set of conditions of service, including the payment of special allowances. In addition, the Treasurer will be seeking an amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act to exempt the pay and allowances earned by Defence Force personnel while they are on tour with UNTAG. Repatriation benefits appropriate to the tasks and hazards encountered will also be provided.

Mr President, our contribution to UNTAG and our involvement in the Namibian settlement makes Australia party to what may be one of the United Nations' most substantial achievements for many years. We have been involved in this process from the start. Australia has been a member of the UN Council for Namibia since 1974. We pledged our support for UNTAG at the inception of the UN plan for Namibia in 1978. Australia also made an important contribution to UN deliberations about Namibia during our recent term on the UN Security Council in 1985-86.

Our participation in UNTAG also builds on the constructive role successive Australian Governments have played on southern African issues. I pay particular tribute to the achievements of former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser in this regard. Our decisive contribution to the attainment of independence by Zimbabwe, Australia's leading role in the Commonwealth on southern Africa affairs, our bilateral aid support for the member countries of the Southern African Development Co-ordination Conference all speak of a firm commitment to peace and stability in that region. Our involvement in the Eminent Person's Group was only one demonstration of our longstanding determination to work constructively to bring about an end to the repugnant policies of apartheid.

I believe that the Namibian settlement, together with the resolution of the Iran-Iraq war and the end of Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan, marks a renewal of faith in the UN as an effective participant in international affairs after many years of cynicism and apathy about its role. The UN belongs on the centre stage of world affairs, not in the wings, and it is very encouraging that more and more countries are recognising this. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the efforts of Martti Ahtisaari, the UN Secretary-General's Special Representative on Namibia, for his important role, and those of the late Bernt Carlsson, the UN Commissioner for Namibia, who was tragically killed in the Lockerbie air disaster.

I would like to think that Namibia's transition to independence will proceed to plan and that there will be no major setbacks. But such things are never certain. Our effort in Namibia will be the largest peacekeeping commitment in which this country has ever participated. It may also be the most difficult. I am sure that all honourable senators, and the people of Australia join me in wishing our troops well in their endeavours. We do so in the knowledge that they will make an outstanding contribution to the future peace and prosperity of an independent Namibian people and a more stable region.

SPEECH.PARA: The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody has attracted a great deal of attention. To some extent the value of the Royal Commission has already been demonstrated by some of the facts which have been disclosed in the interim report. Honourable senators will recall that during the early period of the Commission there was a period of some difficulty with regard to the Commissioner. We unanimously passed a resolution supporting the Commissioner and the operations of the Commission. It would be common ground that there is a general wish in this chamber that some good should come out of this inquiry.

Having said that, there is in the community some doubts about the efficiency of this particular way of getting to the bottom of what is, after all, not a particularly new problem. I say that because one matter which was certainly not known to me at the time the Commission was appointed, but which has become apparent from the facts brought forward in this interim report, is that when one looks at the tragic number of Aboriginal deaths in custody one finds that there are a lot of non-Aboriginal deaths as well. Indeed, the report suggests that the proportion of deaths of Aboriginal people in custody is, if anything, slightly less than the proportion of Aboriginal people in custody. In other words, the proportion of Aboriginal people going into custody who are then dying is slightly less than the proportion of non-Aboriginal people who go into custody and who die in custody or while in prison.

We have a situation in which what the Commission has identified is a problem which affects the whole of the prison community, not merely the Aboriginal community. That, of course, does not in any way make it less of a problem. It suggests that it may not be as racially based as perhaps all of us assumed at the time the Commission was appointed. In one sense I would like to think that that was so and that my own theories as to why Aboriginal people are dying in custody-and this is to some extent borne out in this interim report-may not be correct. The report says:

The social reasons are complex and cannot . . . be fully addressed . . . The explanations . . . do not all lie within prison walls or the confines of lock-ups, nor are they explicable only in terms of sentencing policies.
The Royal Commissioner goes on to say:

I am confident a significant number of deaths have their roots, not only in health issues, but in the very despair of individuals, in frustration, in anger, in legal practices and procedures in which many Aborigines have no confidence.

My personal view was that the deaths were a combination of despair on the part of the Aboriginal people concerned and the contempt they often find within the community-I suspect they sometimes find it in the prison authorities, but that is something which is in no sense peculiar to those authorities; it is unhappily one of the less pleasant aspects of our society-that combination of despair and contempt which would lead people to take their own lives is perhaps something which is felt by many other people in the community. Hence the non-Aboriginal deaths in custody is roughly of a similar proportion.

The serious issue for Aboriginal people is, of course, that so many more Aboriginal people go to gaol. There is a totally disproportionate number of Aboriginal people who find themselves in gaol, compared with their share of the population. The thing we should note in this essentially preliminary comment on these reports is that that problem is one which has been identified for many years.

Many honourable senators would have met the late Elizabeth Eggleston who wrote a book entitled Fear, Favour or Affection, which was a study and really in book form her thesis subtitled `Aborigines and the Criminal Law in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia'. It was published as part of the Aborigines in Australian Society series under the late Professor Charles Rowley. I will very quickly refer to that book, which was published, I point out, in 1976. We find that this contrasting pattern of arrest for Aboriginals is quite different from that for the rest of the population. Elizabeth Eggleston reported:
The Aboriginal offence par excellence is drunkenness, with charges constituting 48 per cent of all charges against Aborigines.
From the reports, it would sadly appear that that is still a major cause of imprisonment, and there are recommendations which relate to that major cause of arrest. We also find:
Thus, Aborigines, forming 2.5 per cent of the population of Western Australia and being convicted of 11 per cent of offences, made up 24 per cent of the prison population of the State.
This goes back 20 years. This is not a new problem. It is an old tragedy. It is time we directed our attention to it in a very constructive way and found some answers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse Senator Chaney's remarks. In fact in the adjournment debate last Thursday I spoke about two white deaths in custody. This is a matter which concerns us all. I am pleased that we will continue this debate at a later time and in greater detail. In speaking briefly to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody interim report, I must say that I do so with a heavy heart. The Commission was established towards the end of 1987 and was expected to complete its work within 12 months. Everyone I know is appalled and sickened by the black deaths in custody, which are still continuing. The interim report is welcome and it provides us with useful information. It is clear that the Commission's research programs are far from complete. Nevertheless, Commissioner Muirhead has made some suggestions and recommendations dealing with issues which must be considered to be not only important but also deserving of immediate consideration by State governments.

SPEECH.PARA: In all, Commissioner Muirhead puts forward some 56 recommendations, with the main focus of attention being on sentencing practices; intoxicated persons; conditions and procedures at police lockups; the recruitment, training and placement of police and prison officers; medical issues; and coronial inquests. The public response to the recommendations has been varied and, on occasions, far from exemplary. There seems to be something close to universal acceptance that imprisonment should be utilised with much less frequency and not imposed automatically in default of payment of fines and that the offence of public drunkenness should either be decriminalised or abolished. Implementation of some of the recommendations on the conditions and procedures at police lockups could well put an end to deaths in custody. I refer briefly to an example of this. Recommendation 12 reads:

In no case should a person be transported by police to a lockup or watch-house when that person is either unconscious or not easily roused. Such persons must, if found on a patrol, be immediately taken to a hospital or medical practitioner or, if neither facility is available, to a nurse or other person qualified to assess their health.

There have been disappointing reactions in Western Australia from representatives of the police and prison officers unions as to the recommendations on the recruitment, training and placement of police and prison officers. For example, recommendation 27 states:

Appropriate screening procedures should be implemented to ensure that potential officers who will have contact with Aboriginal people in their duties are not recruited or retained by police and prison departments whilst holding racist views which cannot be eliminated by training or re-training programs.

There is a great uproar in Western Australia about that and similar recommendations. The recommendations with regard to greater understanding of Aboriginal history, culture and social behaviour make very good sense. If the recommendations on medical issues were implemented now, they would prevent those Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal deaths in custody which are caused directly by police and prison officers not being instructed to seek medical attention immediately. I refer to recommendation 38 which states:
Correctional institutions should have 24 hour a day access to medical practitioners.

That is another very important recommendation. With regard to post-death investigations or coronial inquiries, Commissioner Muirhead recommends greater independence for the coroner's court and less reliance on the outcome of the autopsy and assumptions by the police and prison warders on the cause of death. Commissioner Muirhead says that suicide must never be presumed. We have a long way to go. If some of the recommendations could be implemented right now I think we could prevent such deaths, which, unfortunately, still continue.

I hope that such action will continue and receive the priority that it enjoys currently. I move:
That the debate be now adjourned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The tabling of the 1987-88 report of the Northern Land Council is shrouded in controversy. All of that controversy is of the making of the Northern Land Council itself. I am of the opinion that, unfortunately, in the past couple of years there has been continued politicisation of the Bureau of the Northern Land Council in particular. This arises on many issues when priorities need to be given in the Aboriginal affairs area. I refer to issues such as the Aboriginal treaty: the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, which has been the subject of much debate in this chamber and has been pushed so actively by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand); and the role of the Northern Land Council with regard to emerging local government, or what is referred to in the Northern Territory as community government. In fact, all the issues that were promoted and pushed so strongly by the Northern Land Council at the Barunga festival in June last year point in that direction.

The report points to a number of areas of efficiency, accountability and staffing. A whole range of notes to the accounts that are covered at the back need particular attention. We need to challenge the Bureau of the Northern Land Council to ensure that, as it is a Public Service bureaucracy, it is measured in similar terms to the Public Service. It needs to develop performance indicators to ensure that the functions it carries out are being done effectively for the Aboriginal constituency that it represents and to ensure financial accountability at all times. I think everyone would accept that in the period that the Northern Land Council has been in existence it has had to do a very difficult task. Often it has chosen to hide behind the principles of Aboriginal self-determination that are generally so misunderstood. I am sure nobody would argue that efficiency and accountability ought not to be the measuring stick of all these issues.

I wish to highlight some differences between this and the previous year's report. In that report the auditor put in qualifications, particularly regarding the administration of the royalty trust account. In the previous year it was not covered adequately and reconciled. This year there is no similar qualification, but I have become aware that, since the end of the financial year commencing June 1988, there have been continuing problems concerning royalties, particularly the administration of buffalo royalties in the Northern Territory. I have had allegations made to me that the administration of that area is very loose. It certainly requires a heck of a lot of personal attention, both by the Minister and by the Northern Land Council itself.

The accounts are qualified particularly in the notes at the back of the report relating to the overflow of actual expenditure as against budgeted expenditure for the year. There has been a blow-out in the operational area, in particular. The administration costs involved are substantial. All honourable senators should give close attention to this area of Aboriginal affairs. Often the problem is due to inadequately trained staff who perhaps need special training programs. The Northern Land Council is always aware of this, but it needs to make sure that the administration of the Bureau is not run by a gang of four-or indeed by any small group of people-who do not have sufficient resources or an adequate training background.

In recent months we have seen a number of breakaway land council movements in the Aboriginal constituency in the Northern Territory. They reflect the disquiet and frequent problems in this area. Aboriginal people themselves see the need to get much tighter administration. The Minister, Mr Hand, must give attention to the calls and demands of these breakaway groups. They are very meaningful. On behalf of the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory I point out that they demand urgent attention.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I believe that the annual report of the Central Land Council for 1987-88 needs the close attention of honourable senators. These documents are often couched in such a way that they look like reports of organisations that are proceeding with a great deal of success. Like the Northern Land Council, the Central Land Council has attracted a great deal of controversy. That is easy to cope with in the context of the continuing political debate. There have been breakaway movements within the Aboriginal constituency represented by the Central Land Council. At Docker River on the Western Australian border and in the areas close to Hermannsburg and Ti-Tree, groups of Aboriginal people are expressing their disquiet at the Central Land Council's administration and are asking for smaller, more accountable organisations to represent them.

If one looks at the annual report of the Central Land Council, one notes that the auditor's report by Price Waterhouse is, in a number of instances, couched in rather unusual terms which, I believe, are qualifications that the audit procedures have not necessarily been carried out as they ought to have been. I do not wish to be seen in any way as patronising the way in which Aboriginal people do their accounting, but the cash accountability procedures that have been used were discontinued by most commercial organisations 30 or 40 years ago. Cash disbursements can be made and are open to questioning. But we must ensure, as I said in regard to the Northern Land Council's report, that the people who are destined to receive the cash do receive it, particularly royalty moneys. As I said, this report also demands the close attention of all honourable senators and must be read with regard to the other initiatives that are going on.

I draw a comparison between the reports of the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council and the report of the Tiwi Land Council, which was also tabled today. The Tiwi Land Council report is in very different language. The Tiwi Land Council has different objectives and achievements. As I said last year, when the reports of these three very important Northern Territory Aboriginal land councils were tabled, it is interesting to note that the style and activities of the Tiwi Land Council are quite different from those of the more politicised Northern and Central Land Councils. In their case a number of outside people are more directly involved in their activities.

The Tiwi people are a much smaller group. They are island contained, on Bathurst and Melville Islands, north of Darwin. They have entered into a number of commercial agreements that are complementary to the Aboriginal lifestyle and the aspirations of Aboriginal people. Because they are able culturally to link together and identify with each other so much more closely than the diverse groups represented by the Northern and Central Land Councils, they are in a position to be much more successful. TALK.START.PARA: —The time allowed for the consideration of Government papers has now expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fifteenth report of the Committee of Privileges, entitled Possible False or Misleading Evidence Before a Senate Estimates Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
On 6 December 1988 the Senate referred the following matters to the Committee:

Whether false or misleading evidence was given to a Senate Estimates Committee in relation to the Department of Defence Project known as Project Parakeet, and whether a contempt of the Senate was committed in the giving of that evidence.

The Committee, having received and considered submissions from Dr M. K. McIntosh and Major-General D. Francis, has concluded that there was no intention to give any false or misleading evidence to a Senate Estimates Committee in relation to the Department of Defence project known as Project Parakeet. It follows, therefore, that no contempt of the Senate was committed in the giving of that evidence.

The Committee points out that Dr McIntosh has made an explanation in his submission of the possible misleading of senators and apologises for any deficiency in the phrasing of his responses. The Committee accepts the explanation and apology contained in the submission, but makes the point that if Dr McIntosh had been as helpful to the Senate Estimates Committee as he has been to the Privileges Committee the present exercise would have been avoided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Giles in her capacity as the Chairperson of the Committee of Privileges in presenting the report on this reference on behalf of the Committee. This reference to the Committee arose from a matter which was raised in the Senate on 29 November last year by Senator MacGibbon in remarks he was making on the Appropriation Bill. He focused on certain evidence that was given by the Estimates Committee of which he was a member which had been considering the Estimates for the Department of Defence. The report of that Committee then became part of the discussion on the Appropriation Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon was concerned about the attitude that had been shown to, and the evidence that had been given to, the Committee by a Dr McIntosh, a very senior public servant in charge of capital procurement in the Department of Defence. He is a public servant who has had a great deal of experience in appearing before Estimates committees and, no doubt, other parliamentary committees. His attitude to the Committee could certainly not be construed as the attitude of someone who had little experience of appearing before committees or who was appearing before such a committee for the first time. From his experience of many years of sitting on Estimates committees, particularly in relation to the Department of Defence and certain other departments, Senator MacGibbon also had concerns that there had been a lack of cooperation on the part of many witnesses. Indeed, in his speech in the Senate on 29 November 1988 he quoted his own words spoken on a previous occasion when he said:
The effect has been that far too many witnesses who have appeared before us have given us answers that are obstructive, evasive and at times misleading . . .

In his experience this was not the first time that had happened. It had been happening for a long period on many committees, although probably Senator MacGibbon was speaking mainly about his experiences with the public servants appearing on behalf of the Department of Defence.

The particular problem that gave rise to this reference is set out in the report of the Senate Committee of Privileges which, in appendix 2, incorporates Senator MacGibbon's speech of 29 November. That speech itself incorporates in Hansard the offending passages of the examination of Dr McIntosh. Three senators were questioning Dr McIntosh on Project Parakeet. They wanted to know the true position in the light of a number of press reports which had been made just prior to the hearing of the Estimates Committee on 21 April 1988. Presumably some other information had also been given to the senators. Senator Newman was the first to raise a question about Project Parakeet. She asked:
Is the contract going ahead?
Dr McIntosh answered:
At this stage there are no decisions that would affect additional estimates.
That is hardly an adequate reply to that question, which was the first on the subject. Then Senator Newman raised the question of whether Project Parakeet was in doubt. Dr McIntosh replied:
I think that speculation of that kind is premature.

Again that is hardly an adequate response to a question of whether it was in doubt. In fact, as it turns out now, it was not in doubt. I do not know why Dr McIntosh could not have said so at the time. That drove Senator Newman to make a classic comment on the whole of Dr McIntosh's evidence. She said:
You make me more suspicious than ever by your answers.

That sums up the normal reaction of all the senators resulting from their experiences which followed. Senator MacGibbon then asked whether there were considerable technical problems with Parakeet. He was told by Dr McIntosh that that was an overstatement. I ask honourable senators to note that I am simply quoting the actual answers. Those were the answers given. Senator MacGibbon then asked:
Is it not true that one of the major subcontractors is in difficulty?
Dr McIntosh replied:
I think that, too, is an overstatement.
There was no suggestion about the extent to which that subcontractor may have been in difficulty. Then Senator Newman asked whether the project was way over budget. Dr McIntosh replied:
At this stage, no.
As it turned out later there was no evidence that it was over budget at all at that stage. Finally, Senator Newman asked:
Is it behind schedule?
Dr McIntosh replied:
Not significantly, no.
As it turned out later, it was not behind schedule at that stage, so I do not know what the answer `not significantly, no' means.
Even more extraordinary were some of the answers given to Senator Hill by Dr McIntosh. Senator Hill asked:
Are reports in the Press that the project is likely to be reopened for tender untrue?

Dr McIntosh gave some explanation pointing out that at that time the matter had not gone to tender and the existing contractor who had been performing earlier phases of this project had been asked to provide some estimates. There was no public tender so clearly there was no question of reopening the tender. It was a question of whether the Government intended to accept these offers for the later stage by the contractor. Dr McIntosh explained this and then Senator Hill said-quite correctly in the light of the information:
So, therefore, reference to having to reopen a tender would appear to be incorrect?
It was not a question of reopening a tender because no tenders had been called at that stage. To that question Dr McIntosh replied:
I am sorry; I have not said that at all.

In these highlights of this interchange between the three senators and Dr McIntosh we have a very clear picture and the tasty flavour of the sort of examination that went on. In the light of this, I am not at all surprised that Senator MacGibbon complained about this matter, raised it in the Senate and referred it to the Committee of Privileges. As it subsequently turned out in the later Estimates Committee, there had been some unsatisfactory features of this contractor and the Government had decided to give him away and call tenders. That was the stage, six months later, at which Senator MacGibbon raised the matter and it was referred to the Privileges Committee.

I believe, as Senator Giles has said, if fuller information had been given to the Estimates Committee and Dr McIntosh's approach to the Estimates Committee had been the same as it was to the Committee of Privileges, apart from one qualification-and Dr McIntosh's submission to the Committee of Privileges and a statement by Major-General Francis, who was also a witness before the Estimates Committee, are set out in Appendix 3-I am sure that the Estimates Committee would have been satisfied. Clearly, by the time the matters came before the Committee of Privileges, indeed at the time the matter came before the second Estimates Committee, the problem which was apparently bothering Dr McIntosh-namely, that the Department had put a submission to the Minister that a new contractor should be found for the latter phase and that tenders should be opened-would have been alleviated. I am sure that Senator MacGibbon, Senator Hill and Senator Newman would not suggest that the recommendation that the Department gave the Minister should have been given to the Estimates Committee. We recognise that committees do not have that information given to them, nor would a public servant be pre-empting a Minister, as Dr McIntosh puts forward in his defence, but the situation as it was at the time with the contractor could have been fully explained without giving the information as to what was the Department's advice to the Minister, or indeed what was the Department's attitude to the contractor. It was simply a matter of indicating the factual background at that time, and not fending off questions in the way in which Dr McIntosh did. In his submission to the Privileges Committee Dr McIntosh said:

It is also the practice that officials at the hearings respond to questions from Senators on detailed Explanatory Notes on the Estimates and an opening statement, rather than volunteer information in a more seminar style. If questions are not asked, it is presumed that Senators do not require further information on that item or aspect of the Estimates.

Certainly there were plenty of questions asked by senators, and they made it quite clear that they were not getting enough information. Therefore, I do not know how that statement applies. Dr McIntosh went on in his submission:

While a less formal approach is sometimes adopted, and obviously Senators wanted any or all information they could get on the Parakeet project, it would clearly have been inappropriate for officials to volunteer information and comment in a sensitive area yet to be decided by Government.

This was not a question of their having to volunteer information or comment on a sensitive area. It was simply a matter of giving senators facts which they were entitled to have and which they could quite simply have been given without the public servant having to comment on a sensitive area to be decided by government.

I am rather concerned to read the view of a senior public servant that public servants do not have to volunteer information to a parliamentary committee or an Estimates committee. If it is clear that senators are confused in some way about some aspect of information they have been given, or if clearly they have not received as much information as they want, which was the case here, I think that it is up to public servants to be prepared to volunteer information to try to clear up misunderstandings. That is what the process is all about. If it is to work satisfactorily, as by and large it has done over the years, public servants must have a much more forthcoming attitude than that adopted by Dr McIntosh in the proceedings to which I have referred-certainly a more forthcoming attitude than the view he expressed in his submission to the Committee of Privileges.

I hope that, this matter having been referred to the Privileges Committee, and closer examination having been given to it, as was required of the Committee in order to make a judgment as to whether there had been a contempt by Dr McIntosh in these matters, this will be used beneficially in the future and that public servants will not put themselves in a position where they are suspected of hiding something from a committee and thereby suspected of misleading a committee. Clearly that would be a contempt. It is a fine line to draw in many cases between deliberate misleading and giving technically correct answers. Even in this case it is clear that Dr McIntosh was giving technically correct answers, but giving rise to concerns that information was being withheld beyond what was necessary, desirable or justifiable. Public servants in that position should err on the side of providing as much information as they can, subject to the clear prohibitions on them pre-empting decisions of Ministers or giving evidence about that advice they have given to Ministers.

There was no reason why at these hearings information could not have been volunteered about the actual state of play with this contractor. There had been some technical problems, and they were ironed out later as it turned out. There had been some problems with the management of the company, but apparently those also were ironed out. The whole question revolved around the costs quoted by the company for the later stages. For that reason the Government decided to reopen tenders and those have not been finalised. All that background, issues as to whether the project was in doubt, whether there had been technical problems, whether the contractors were in difficulty, and whether the project was to be significantly delayed are all questions on which Dr McIntosh could have been far more forthcoming, so that this whole exercise could have been avoided. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
