DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT (GENERAL CAPITAL INCREASE) BILL 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was speaking last Friday on the amendments moved by Senator Macklin. Since then I have received via the Treasury some advice from the Office of Parliamentary Counsel which says, among other things:

SPEECH.PARA: In general the amendments are in danger of being outside the scope of the long title.

I do not want to place too much importance on that; I just put it on the record that, because the proposed amendments refer to other Acts, there is some doubt at least as to whether they are technically in order. I dealt last Friday with the degree to which matters are reported in general by the Treasurer under the 1947 legislation. I was dealing with the Australian Democrats' third amendment, regarding the annual report. The first couple of paragraphs of that amendment are fairly innocuous. However, paragraph (c) of proposed new clause 7 (2) requires the report given by the Treasurer to include the following:
an assessment of the activities and effectiveness of the Bank and the affiliates, including their activities and effectiveness in relation to:
(i) the alleviation of poverty;
(ii) the prevention of damage to the environment; and
(iii) obtaining, and taking into account, the views and needs of indigenous peoples . . .

The objective behind it is pretty clear-to extend social engineering on a global scale-but it is fatuous to suggest that any report, even one which had substantive content, on matters which are subject to such extremely subjective judgments would be worth anything. For those reasons, as well as the reasons I put on the record last Friday, the Government will not accept the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposition that Senator Walsh has put up is interesting inasmuch as the second reading debate on the Bill canvassed these issues fairly extensively. I do not wish to go back over all of it; I merely mention the fact that neither the United States Congress nor the World Bank agrees with Senator Walsh's views. For example, before the Congress at the moment is a Bill entitled `A Bill to seek the eradication of the worst aspects of poverty in developing countries by the year 2000', which has been signed by 155 House members. Senator Walsh made a point about subjectiveness. It is rather interesting that clause 2, `Specified Goals', on page 5 of that Bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: Among the goals included in the plan developed pursuant to subsection (a) shall be the following:
(A) UNDER-FIVE-MORTALITY-RATE . . .
It then goes through the various levels that it is seeking to obtain in the countries that are provided with aid from the United States of America. It continues:
(B) FEMALE LITERACY RATE . . .
Again, it outlines the levels it seeks to achieve. It seeks a female literacy rate of 80 per cent by the year 2000. It continues:

(C) ABSOLUTE POVERTY LEVEL-For a country having 40 per cent or less of its population below the absolute poverty level in 1985, reducing that percentage by 50 per cent by the year 2000. For a country having greater than 40 per cent of the population below the absolute poverty level, reducing that percentage to no more than 20 per cent by the year 2000.
(D) ECOLOGICAL SUSTAINABILITY . . .
It then goes on to something quite pertinent to the amendment I am raising, and in publication of the plan-Paragraph (L) it states:

ANNUAL REPORTS-Not later than 1 February each year, the President shall submit a report to the Congress detailing progress toward achieving the goals established in the plan developed pursuant to subsection (a). The report should specify, for each activity carried out pursuant to the plan, how that activity is expected to reach one or more of the goals established pursuant to subsection (c).

In other words, other people around the world do not happen to think the attack on poverty is necessarily as subjective as does Senator Walsh. I refer to the last annual report of the World Bank itself. The 1988 annual report, on page 41, referring to poverty alleviation, says:
Poverty alleviation has long been, and continues to be, central to the Bank's work.

It sees that as fundamental. As I suggested in the second reading debate, the World Bank itself has developed a number of procedures for dealing quite specifically with the alleviation of poverty and believes that that ought to be the central criterion on which the effectiveness of the World Bank is judged. That is, it believes it should make a judgment on itself. With respect to the environmental protection aspect, on page 43 of the World Bank's annual report it is stated:

. . . efforts are being made to identify projects, which, while meeting the criteria of economic growth and poverty alleviation, directly address environmental issues or ease the problems of environmental management . . .

The third point I raised in my amendment concerns indigenous peoples. A document I mentioned in my second reading remarks, entitled Environment and Development: Implementing the World Bank's New Policies, published in July 1988, talks of the importance of forging closer links with non-government organisations in countries in receipt of assistance because, amongst other things, they better allow the bank to take into account the needs of indigenous peoples.

We say that this Parliament, similar to the United States Congress and in line with the intentions expressed as late as the middle of last year by the World Bank itself, should focus on those three issues. The point of our amendment is to ensure that Australia's ongoing representatives on the Executive Board in Washington and Australia's representative on the Board of Governors, the Treasurer, support and encourage the bank's works in these areas. We believe that it is necessary, in terms of any further items in this Bill, to provide to this Parliament information that will enable us to monitor what Australia has been saying and doing in the World Bank with regard to these particular items. I understand the sensitivity of Treasury and other bureaucracies about sharing with the Parliament the information that they have, but I think this is one occasion, in view of the number of signatures from members of the Opposition and the Government on precisely these issues, on which the Parliament is entitled to this type of information.

As I mentioned before in referring to the International Monetary Agreements Act, the Treasurer's annual report provides none of this information. It has not been provided to date and I see no reason why it should not be provided in the future. It would specifically address that arm of the World Bank, or the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, with which this Bill is concerned. That is what we are seeking. We are seeking to find out the response of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to Australia's move to back up what is now the undoubted policy of the World Bank in this area. It is perfectly in accordance with the Act and the processes of this Parliament that we should have that type of information. From what we have been able to discover, that information is held by Treasury. If it is held by Treasury, it should be a simple matter to inform the Parliament of such so that next time a Bill appears requesting further assistance for the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development we will be in a position to make an informed judgment about what has happened in the year or two since the passing of the Bill before us tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a rather narrow point that arises out of that portion of the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats calling for an annual report to be presented. I have no problem with the call for a report. I think there is already provision under a much earlier Act for a report to be issued. However, the report required here would be a much more detailed one. Subparagraph (c) of proposed new clause (7) in Senator Macklin's amendment calls on the Treasurer to present in this report:

SPEECH.PARA: an assessment of the activities and effectiveness of the Bank and the affiliates-
that is, the International Development Association and the International Finance Corporation-
-including their activities and effectiveness in relation to:
(i) the alleviation of poverty;
(ii) the prevention of damage to the environment; and
(iii) obtaining, and taking into account, the views and needs of indigenous peoples,
in countries affected by the activities of the Bank and the affiliates.''.

With all respect to the views of those who run around the world depicting the World Bank as a new moloch devouring, through its activities, the resources of the world in the interests of some kind of international capitalism-or other figment of the tortured imaginations of the people in question-the truth of the matter is that the World Bank is a very successful and, in my opinion, notwithstanding some criticisms I have, very responsible international financial assistance agency. Notwithstanding the highly coloured accounts which one receives about the President of the World Bank being personally responsible for the greenhouse effect which, if we are not provident and careful, is about to overwhelm us in the next six months, or because of the bank's activities in Brazil or elsewhere, the facts, as distinct from the figments of these people's imaginations, are that the World Bank is getting on with what it is required to do by its charter. Australia is a member of the institution and subscribes to that charter. The charter states that the bank should help to provide development assistance, in one form or another, to most of the developing country members of the bank.

Firstly, if the bank is successful in that objective-and I regard it as being, with some qualifications, certainly successful-it is by definition contributing to `the alleviation of poverty', which is the first subset of Senator Macklin's demands for this report to focus upon. On the question of the second of the matters listed, namely, the prevention of damage to the environment, it is obviously true that the processes of economic development do inevitably, to some degree, conflict with the total preservation, or conservation, of the previously existing environment. That fact is not in debate. The only question in the perpetual debates that rage on this subject is-and always has been-whether the contribution which is thereby made in order to enhance the lot of the peoples of the developing countries concerned outweighs, in terms of human happiness the inevitable damage to the environment which is caused by, for example, the damming of a river in Brazil, or the clearing of some land for a major road, or perhaps the planting of crops where previously none were grown.

However distressing that fact may be to the people who are rich enough to take their holidays to these far-flung, romantic and relatively savage places, the truth of the matter is that that is not the chief concern of the World Bank. The chief concern of the World Bank is the alleviation of the lot of the peoples who presently have to live in these places and present themselves for the cameras of the passing tourists. While much may be said about the damage to the environment in these places, we should bear firmly in mind that any damage to the environment is incidental to what the governments and the people of those countries have as a more important objective, namely, the raising of their desperately low standard of living.

Finally, the third head of demand put forward in subparagraph (c) of Senator Macklin's amendment is that the report which the Treasurer of the day has been called on to make-I suspect it will not be the current Treasurer (Mr Keating) by the time the amendment becomes effective-should take into account the views and needs of indigenous peoples. The mind boggles at the thought of the Treasurer of the Commonwealth somehow taking independent action to ascertain how the World Bank's activities and effectiveness measure up against the objective of obtaining and taking into account the views and needs of indigenous peoples in countries affected by the activities of the bank and the affiliates. What is the Treasurer to do? Is he to pay a personal visit to the jungles of the Amazon? I know that, to the Australian Democrats, public moneys are of no account; but is the Treasurer supposed to send an expensive mission to be led by, for example, Colonel Sanders on my left here? Is he to come back and present to the Treasurer a report as ill informed as his reports to this Parliament normally are on other matters, particularly environmental matters?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are getting angry. I am glad to see that.

—No, I am not getting angry in the least. Senator Sanders is not worth getting angry about. I want to point out the extraordinary ineffectiveness, or pointlessness, of the third head of the amendment. I can see a case for saying it would be possible for the Treasurer to report on the first two points-the World Bank's activities in relation to the alleviation of poverty and the prevention of damage to the environment, although there may be many problems with the second point-but the last point, `obtaining, and taking into account, the views and needs of indigenous peoples', has nothing to do with anything other than the fact that it happened to be a fad running in the newspapers and, as so often occurs, the Australian Democrats picked it up and ran with it. That is their wont; that is what finally gave them their comeuppance in the Australian Capital Territory election last Saturday. If the election had no other beneficial result, at least it showed the due esteem in which the Australian Democrats are held by the people of the Australian Capital Territory. The Democrats got 1.3 per cent of the vote.
—We outpolled the National Party.

—The National Party has never made a strong pitch for representation in a town of public servants and is never likely to. Let me get back to the more clear purpose of my remarks; that is to say that, notwithstanding some of the things I have been saying about the Australian Democrats, I would have hoped for, and indeed expected Senator Macklin to accept the fact that what he is calling on the Treasurer of the Commonwealth to do is something which is not really sensibly within his power to do as far as subparagraph (iii) is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as subparagraph (i) is concerned, it can tell us nothing other than what it does. Of course the activity of the World Bank has been useful and constructive in the cause of the alleviation of poverty. So far as subparagraph (ii) is concerned-the prevention of damage to the environment-of course there has been some damage to the environment and there is bound to be always when the process of economic development occurs. The only question is, at the risk of repeating myself, whether or not in the judgment of reasonable people, and particularly the judgment of the peoples of the countries concerned who are the ones most affected by this after all-not, as I said, the passing parade of American millionaires or other millionaires who want to go down and take photographs of the place-that damage to the environment is more than outweighed by the improvement in the standards of living of the people who have to live in those countries.

I simply want to say before I conclude that I have no problem at all with the greater part of the amendment proposed by the Democrats, but as to paragraph (c), I strongly say that this is simply an appeal in the best populist Democrat tradition; namely, the kind of thing which they think will get them a headline or two or will enhance their standing with some particular interest group or other of a marginal kind. I do not believe that it would be sensible to support this particular subparagraph of the amendment. I am perfectly happy, for myself at any rate, to support the amendment for the most part, but I think that subparagraph (ii) paragraph (c) is a nonsense. I do not think the Parliament should be enacting nonsenses.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate last Friday when we were winding up fairly quickly at the end, I drew the attention of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to the existence of the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947 which I understood required the Government to report to the Parliament about the operations of the World Bank from time to time. In his response, which admittedly was under pressure of time as we got close to Question Time, I do not think he had the opportunity fully to develop all the points that were relevant to the debate. For that reason, I would like to just ask him again whether he has had the opportunity to scan the last few minutes of the Hansard of Friday to see whether the issues that were covered in the Australian Democrats' amendment which we are now discussing are part of the requirements to be reported under that rather old Act. That point did not emerge, I do not think, in the course of Senator Walsh's remarks last Friday. It is now that assurance that I am seeking his advice about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I did deal with that matter on Friday, although I have not had a look at the Hansard. Further to the Treasury note from which I quoted fairly extensively on Friday, I now have here the most recent 1987-88 report under the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947 to which I referred. Just inside the flyleaf, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Under section 10 of the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947, the Treasurer is required to prepare and cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament, as soon as practicable after the end of each financial year, a report on the operations of the Act and of the operations in so far as they relate to Australia of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) during the financial year. This report in respect of the financial year 1987-88 is presented accordingly.

In other words, apart from the question I raised about the possible technical defectiveness of all the amendments that have been moved, the Government's position is that while the amendments are at best superfluous-that is, amendments (i) and (ii)-amendment (iii) is I think, as Senator Stone has demonstrated more amply than I did, really rather absurd. If the Senate decides to press this amendment and pass it, it will not be at all difficult I suppose for somebody in the Treasury to write that he has done this sort of an assessment. He could say, `But we came to the conclusion that it is too hard and we cannot really report anything meaningful'. That really would not do much harm, I do not suppose, except to make a bit of a laughing stock of the Senate for having passed such an amendment in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a contribution. Before I do so, I refer to a point that was made by Senator Macklin and a response made by Senator Walsh. As I understood it, Senator Macklin was indicating that it was of considerable importance that the activities and effectiveness of the bank be considered against the background as to whether its activities were alleviating poverty. I was not actually impressed with the response by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in respect of that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Minister that the former Australian Foreign Minister, Bill Hayden, subtly criticised the World Bank's loan conditionality. I will quote from a special survey of the World Bank IMF. The article is entitled `The World Bank sticks to its guns' in Triple A of September 1988. I will not make any comment about the journal one way or the other because that is not appropriate during this debate. Quoting Bill Hayden, it stated:

World Bank lending to support structural adjustment in developing countries has caused controversy. Although the adoption of appropriate policies is necessary if a country is to develop, the poor can be hurt in the process . . .

I think that is a matter which the Committee is attempting to focus its attention upon. I also refer to comments that were made in the World Development Report 1988 which is a study of major development issues written by the staff of the World Bank. It has a short article on the World Bank's evolving role in public expenditure reviews. It was citing studies which document the higher lifetime productivity of workers and which suggested that health investments improve `the productivity of labour force'.

From my trade union background, I raise that as a real query as to whether the focus of its health investments is to improve the productivity of the labour force. I am not saying that that is precisely what the World Bank is on about, but I am indicating that this report did cite those studies. I consider it most important to establish a major principle-that is, that development must always centre on humans, the dignity of the human being and human rights. Any development that goes against that principle is just not authentic development, and ultimately not only will cause direct problems to the individuals in developing countries but will also have a backlash against those countries that are the highest contributors to the World Bank, namely, the Western countries. It would be easy and correct to suggest that any development that did not uphold that major principle would really be an attempt at neo-imperialism.

In saying that, I do not wish to canvass the issues which were canvassed at the second reading stage. I only regret that I was not here on Friday at the second reading stage. Frankly, I had expected the second reading stage to have continued today. I wish to focus on Senator Macklin's amendment, which has a number of points about it. It states:
. . . the Treasurer shall prepare and cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament a report on the operations of this Act during that financial year.
It also states that there should be:
(a) a statement of the terms and conditions of any agreement or agreements made by the Treasurer;
(b) a statement describing the nature and extent of Australia's participation as a member of the Bank and the affiliates during that year;
(c) an assessment of the activities and effectiveness of the Bank and the affiliates, including their activities and effectiveness in relation to:
(i) the alleviation of poverty;
(ii) the prevention of damage to the environment; and
(iii) obtaining, and taking into account, the views and needs of indigenous peoples.

I think it is common ground around the chamber that such a specific report should be laid before the Houses of Parliament. As honourable senators would know, there has been concern about damage to the environment. I have touched upon the first matter-that is to say, the alleviation of poverty-and I have indicated that, as the World Bank is one of the major, if not the major, multilateral providers of funds, it should have regard to that principle of authentic development that I enunciated earlier.

As we all know, there has been considerable worldwide discussion about the prevention of damage to the environment and the World Bank has addressed itself to that question. Indeed, in its annual report of 1988 it refers to a paper on environmental activities which was developed in 1987. That paper, entitled Environment, Growth and Development, was prepared by the bank for submission to the Development Committee at its meeting in Washington, DC. It is interesting to note what is in this paper. The 1988 annual report of the World Bank had this to say about the paper:
It-
namely, the paper-

stressed both the importance of addressing environmental issues in the context of overall economic policy, rather than simply by concern with individual projects, and the overriding importance of the effects of rapid population growth.

That comment attempts to obscure some of the legitimate concerns about particular projects which were environmentally unsound and seeks to lump it all on the effects of rapid population growth. We have seen too much of that go unchallenged in the international sphere. We have seen it at international conferences, without analysing the very strong academic and economic arguments that have been advanced to the effect that the problem is not rapid population growth but real structural problems that developing countries have, both internally and in the management of their foreign debt. Because of time constraints I cannot refer to a number of the quite erudite papers that have examined that question and found that this sort of glib reference to rapid population growth as being the main problem has been addressed and demolished.
It is important to know what the third point that has been made in Senator Macklin's amendment means. Paragraph (iii) states:
obtaining, and taking into account, the views and needs of indigenous people.

I go to this question of human rights. I went to the Philippines last year. A great deal of concern was expressed both in non-government and in official circles about the arm twisting that is done by the World Bank in an attempt to impose population control methods which are unacceptable to the people of those countries. I also refer to a scheme that the World Bank has now entered into, that is, the HRP program-the human reproduction program-which is developing abortion drugs, chemical weapons to be used against the unborn. I believe that we should be seriously concerned about this and also acknowledge the dangers of any policies which would give sustenance to the types of population control policies for example, in China and in some very near neighbours, which amount to a denial of human rights. I would like to be assured that the Government will take that on board. I am not sure whether that is what is meant by this third point in the amendment:
obtaining, and taking into account, the views and needs of indigenous peoples.

I would like the Minister to explain again, as I was not too clear on what he just said in response to Senator Messner, whether a report along these lines is required to be tabled in the Parliament and whether it would deal with it in such specific terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, of course it wouldn't. It would be about a foot high if it did.

—The Minister said it would be about a foot high. The World Bank addresses the alleviation of poverty. The World Bank addresses all of these things. I am wondering whether the report that the Minister is referring to will have this in it or whether it will be a series of projects and the funding arrangements which have been made relating to those projects. If it is the latter, that adds more weight to the amendment that has been moved by Senator Macklin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this debate quite revealing in a number of ways. The most prominent way is probably the way it reveals the views and opinions of the National Party of Australia and, I suppose, the Government towards indigenous peoples. We have had Senator Walsh saying that it would make a laughing stock of the Senate to pass this amendment which would require a report of the assessment of the views and needs of the indigenous people. We found Senator Stone saying that the mind boggles if the Treasurer (Mr Keating) were to take heed of indigenous people in this way. He said it was impossible to determine the impact of the World Bank on indigenous peoples.
—They are trying to do it themselves.

—Yes, the World Bank is trying to do it itself. Senator Stone seems to equate development with the advancement of the standard of living and he defended the World Bank's past activities. He is becoming increasingly lonely in his defence of its past activity, even in terms of the employees of the World Bank itself.

SPEECH.PARA: The World Bank has been ruled in the past by economics. I think it was Thomas Carlyle who called economics the dismal science. I am not even sure it is a science.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not.

—It is not a science, as Senator Stone said. Economics is not regarded as a friend of the earth. Economic progress destroys and modifies natural environments. It makes the quality of the environment a dispensable item in the pursuit of `rising living standards'. We hear a lot about how we would like to maintain our living standards. A lot of people on this earth simply want to live. They simply want to survive. I would like to quote from a New Scientist article dated 7 July 1988 entitled `Sustained hope for development'. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is more or less official: much of the activity we call development destroys the topsoil, fresh water, atmospheric systems and genetic resources upon which human progress must be based. It is hard to say just when it became official. Perhaps it happened in London on the night of 3 March, when David Hopper, vice president of the World Bank for policy, planning and research, explained how and why the bank often spent large sums to ruin good agricultural land.
This is not a greenie organisation. He is an official of the World Bank itself. The article goes on:

Hopper worked for 10 years as an anthropologist and agriculturalist in India. He realised that irrigating land without installing drainage would inevitably create a salty swamp. Then he became a vice president of the World Bank, with responsibility for projects in South Asia. One of the first schemes he was asked to approve was for irrigation without drainage. He said no. His staff patiently explained to the new boy that because the land was already highly productive, the added cost of putting in drains meant that the project would fail the bank's test of a return of 10 per cent on investment. Besides, the Government receiving the aid was keen on the project. Hopper approved it.
Hopper approved it in spite of his own opinion and expertise. The article went on:

Hopper said this incident shows that: ``The accepted economic justification for proceeding with the investment was certain to lead to a degrading of the resource base, and there was no acceptable justification for protecting those resources from destruction''. Hopper was letting this particular cat out of the World Bank's bag, but in doing so he was damning what he called ``the anomaly of economic calculus'' that governs the decisions of all aid agencies and the world's ministers of agriculture, forestry, fisheries and so on.

Planners and economists often fail to open their spread-sheets wide enough to cover the consequences of development. First, they cannot deal with the value of resources not defined by the market: trees that protect a tropical watershed, or an ozone layer that protects a planet. Secondly, they ``discount'' future values, though common sense tells us that the future value of an intact tropical forest-in terms of timber, genetic resources, water and stable climate-will be no less in the future than now. Thus many developing nations overfarm their land to export commodities to the North.
That means the Northern Hemisphere. To continue:

In doing so they are subsidising the North's purchase of their already cheap commodities by assuming the cost of restoring the lands themselves. Botswana is destroying its grasslands to produce cheap beef for Europe. Botswana, not Europe, will pay the cost of this destruction.

A stronger, more official description of this syndrome came from the World Commission on Environment and Development (WCED). Headed by Gro Harlem Bruntland, the prime minister of Norway, it reached its conclusions only after three years of hearings in five continents at an expense of $6 million. The commission decided that: ``Many forms of development erode the environmental resources upon which they must be based, and environmental degradation can undermine economic development''.

It goes on and on. We can all quote horror stories about how development has actually degraded the lives of those whose lives it was meant to develop. It may in fact enrich the lives of the `haves' in a poor third world nation because of the trickle down effect; the money goes to the top and very little of it reaches the bottom. When it does it is often in an environmentally hazardous way that does not take any account of the indigenous people. They never ask the people what they want or how best to give it to them. Over and over again we hear of cases where the World Bank furnishes a crop or an agricultural system which, if it had asked the local people, it would have found completely unsuitable. But they never ask the local people. What we are saying in this amendment is, `Let us, at least in Australia, have a mechanism where the local people are considered and asked whether (a) they want the development; (b) will it be a good development; and (c) will it affect their own ways of doing things; their way of life'. That is all this amendment does.

I find it absolutely shameful that senators in this chamber argue against such a development because it means that they do not care about the people of the world who are less fortunate than us. They simply want to go along, churning out their reports in a way which would exclude the indigenous people. I urge support for this amendment. I hope that the Government will see fit to support it. I certainly hope that the Government will also take a good hard look at its responsibilities towards the less fortunate peoples of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the depressing things about these types of debates is that, fairly obviously, the Minister and others do not bother to listen to the second reading debates. I had always assumed that the second reading debates were taken as basic to the types of amendments that one may wish to move during the committee stages. In looking at this amendment and responding, in particular, to Senator Stone's comments, it is rather fascinating-I developed some of these points during my speech in the second reading debate-that the material that is provided to Treasury already happens to include elements with regard to these three proposed new paragraphs.

SPEECH.PARA: I also referred in my speech during the second reading debate to documents that the World Bank has produced. I quoted from them again a little while ago-that is, The World Bank's Support for the Alleviation of Poverty, published in June 1988, and Environment and Development: Implementing the World Bank's New Policies, published in July last year. It is interesting that the World Bank has moved in this direction. It is seeking to take into account those three proposed new paragraphs quite specifically in terms of its funding mechanisms. Senator Stone waved his arms around and made unfounded allegations, but these are not things that the Australian Democrats picked up. In fact, we picked them up by reading World Bank documents. They were the bank's ideas as at the middle of last year. I find it extraordinary that people pay absolutely no attention to a second reading debate in this place and do not do their homework; yet they then come in here and relieve themselves of their prejudices. In quoting extensively from the various documents, it was fairly easy to show that the three items are ones on which the World Bank makes an assessment and now informs our Treasury about. So the material is already provided to us. The material is in our hands, but we need to provide it to the Parliament. Naturally enough, the Government is simply saying `We don't want to tell Parliament anything'. But there is nothing new in that.

I am not alone in my view. As I suggested before, over 100 members of both Houses of the Parliament, including a number of people who are in here at the moment-Senator Messner was among them-signed the letters referring quite specifically to three items, which are covered by the three paragraphs in my amendment. The letters are in the Hansard record. Senator Hill, who is a shadow Minister, was one of the main instigators in collecting signatures for the letters. Senator Teague, who is in here at the moment, and Senator Harradine signed the letters. The three specified items to which I refer are not new. They have been around for two years and have exercised the independent interest of honourable senators. In fact, the terminology in my amendment was taken specifically from the letters signed by people on whom Senator Stone has just launched scathing criticism. I do not know whether his front bench colleagues appreciated that type of attack. I suppose they can discuss that themselves. It needs to be made very clear that if those members of this chamber, from all political parties, who signed the letters vote against this amendment, they will be repudiating their signatures on the letters. It comes down simply to asking that the material which is currently provided by the World Bank to the Treasury be provided to us in accordance with each of the proposed paragraphs. While Senator Stone reluctantly accepted the first and second paragraphs, he refused to accept the third and said that this was some interesting recent fad.

Debates on matters such as this manage to maintain a reasonably high tone for a while. In fact, I re-read Senator Alston's and Senator Watson's speeches at the second reading stage. They made excellent contributions. There had been detailed research, they had gone back to the original documents and they had troubled to do their homework. Both those people referred quite specifically to the type of support that is necessary from this chamber to enable our Government to put pressure on the World Bank to look at each of those items.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are kidding yourself.
—Senator Stone has not bothered reading them, has he?
—You reckon the World Bank--

—Senator Stone acknowledges that he has not bothered reading Senator Watson's or Senator Alston's contributions. I suggest that he read them because they were quite good contributions. Unless we express our views clearly as to where we believe we should be going with these paragraphs, particularly the one which he rejects totally, we will be in great difficulty. The non-government organisations are playing a very interesting, new and quite innovative and constructive role with regard to indigenous peoples. The World Bank in its most recent documents has expressed a lot more concern about that area. It is of concern to all aid and development agencies. It is not something apart from the alleviation of poverty or environmental degradation. As I attempted to show in my second reading contribution, the paragraphs of the amendment are bound together. They are not separate items; they are part and parcel of the new policies enunciated in the document Environment and Development: Implementing the World Bank's New Policies of July last year. That is an excellent document which shows the way ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned at the beginning of our consideration of the legislation this evening, the United States Congress is seeking further information on these matters from its executives. I do not think that we should be behind in this. It is an important and a developing area of interest for many senators and members. I believe that the additional information will find a ready market because those honourable senators who have already been active in this area will be able to make use of the material to further their own knowledge and understanding and, in doing so, be able to provide a much more informed, and hopefully more in depth, contribution to subsequent debates in this chamber. I hope that honourable senators will support the amendment and that we will get from the Government the material which it already possessed in Treasury documents.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise only to reject the rather characteristic misrepresentation of me by Senator Macklin. At one point in the course of his remarks he referred to the likelihood that, if his amendment were carried, this Parliament would be able to place pressure upon the World Bank-I hope I quote the honourable senator accurately-to undertake a more effective examination of the matters that are referred to in this amendment. At that point I interjected, `You are kidding yourself', to which Senator Macklin responded in a manner which I have to say again is characteristic by saying, `Senator Stone admits that he has not even heard or read Senator Watson's or Senator Alston's speeches'-a matter to which he had referred earlier. I did nothing of the kind, as Senator Macklin was only too well aware.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday when we first started discussing this legislation at the second reading stage, I drew attention on behalf of the Opposition to the Opposition's commitment to the humanitarian objectives of the World Bank in the development of better standards of living for those in lesser developed countries. Indeed, that remains the objective of the Liberal and National parties in our general support for the legislation. However, we did say that there were problems of accountability in respect of the way in which the World Bank in its various arms goes about its business of alleviating poverty throughout the world. Questions have been raised not only in this country but in the United States, as Senator Macklin pointed out, and the bank itself about the effectiveness and the accountability of the various arms of the World Bank in distributing funds. Those are vital matters on behalf of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: A question of accountability is involved here. Senator Macklin's amendment, for the greater part, points strongly to that. The only point of contention before the Committee tonight is paragraph (c) of proposed sub-clause (2) of his amendment, which refers to specific matters which are to be the subject-if the amendment is carried-of report by the Treasurer to the Houses of Parliament. I regret to say that, although I have asked the Minister, Senator Walsh, twice about the application of the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947 and the requirements upon the Government to report subject to that Act, we still are not clear whether or not the Act spells out the specific requirement on the Government to report on the matters mentioned in proposed new paragraph 7 (2) (c)--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Act?
—The International Monetary Agreements Act 1947.
—It doesn't.

—This is the point at issue. About half an hour ago I listened to Senator Walsh say that the Act did cover those things. I want to get this question straight before we proceed to the question of whether the Liberal and National parties will support the Democrat amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have quoted from the report issued annually pursuant to the International Monetary Agreements Act. I do not have a copy of the IMA Act here, so I cannot tell honourable senators what section 10 says precisely as to whether such matters must be reported, but I would be surprised if it were particularly close to the wording of the amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats to clause 7. I leave aside the arguable technical defectiveness of the Democrats' amendments because they exceed the scope of the long title. The Government's view at best is that these amendments are superfluous-or at least, in so far as the amendments mean anything, they are superfluous, particularly the first two of them. The third amendment is, I believe, also superfluous in proposed new subclauses (1), (2) (a) and (2) (b).

SPEECH.PARA: Subclause (2) (c) is so nebulous that I suggest that it means anything or nothing, depending on the preferences of who chooses to interpret it. It certainly does not say, as Senator Macklin suggested, that the Treasurer will provide to the Parliament some information provided to Treasury by the Reserve Bank. What it says-this is not a continuous quotation-is that the Treasurer shall prepare and cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament a report which shall include the effectiveness of the programs of the bank and its affiliates in the alleviation of poverty. I suppose that one could have a stab in the dark; one could probably get somebody to argue that the bank's program was very effective in relieving poverty and somebody else to argue that it had not been. Indeed, we have had that sort of argument tonight, I suggest, between Senator Harradine and the Democrats. So honourable senators can see how meaningful any report which purported to give a definitive evaluation of whether a particular program had been effective in relieving poverty would be.

Proposed new subclause (2) (c) mentions the prevention of damage to the environment. There is little economic development which does not change the environment. Whether it damages the environment or not is again, to a large degree, a subjective judgment. Proposed new subclause (2) (c) mentions obtaining and taking into account the views and needs of indigenous peoples. So, according to the literal interpretation of this amendment, the Treasurer is required to obtain the views of indigenous people and take them into account.

As I said before, I do not believe that it would be hard for some class 9 clerk, or even a class 1 clerk, in the Treasury to comply with the letter of this amendment should it be incorporated into the Act. But whether such a report, in compliance with the letter of the Act, were written by a clerk class 1-the newest clerical recruit-or the Secretary to the Treasury, would not, I suggest, make much difference to its value because it would deal with matters which are so nebulous that to report on them, and purport that that report is a definitive report, is quite absurd. But if the Senate wants to pass the amendment, it will not in my view create any insuperable barriers-anything that cannot be dealt with. But I repeat: I regard the whole exercise as absurd and a waste of the Committee's time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) for his response. I have now obtained a copy of the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947. Article 1 of the first schedule of the Act sets down the purposes of the International Monetary fund quite clearly. Paragraph (ii) of the first article reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: To facilitate the expansion and balanced growth of international trade, and to contribute thereby to the promotion and maintenance of high levels of employment and real income and to the development of the productive resources of all members as primary objectives of economy policy.

Quite clearly, the first subparagraph of the Democrat amendment, which refers to the alleviation of poverty, is covered by the purposes as set down in the schedule to the Act under which the Government is required to report to the Parliament. It seems to us that that point is well and truly covered, as revealed in the Government's argument.

The second and third subparagraphs of proposed new subclause (2) (c) go to questions of the environment and also to the need to obtain and take into account the views and needs of indigenous peoples. In respect of damage to the environment, we have observed that reporting procedures are available through other sources. It was made clear to us by Senator Macklin in the debate that information of this kind is available. It seems to me that the matter is also covered by the general principles of proper management and efficiency of the bank in carrying out its economic objectives. Clearly, the matter would find its way into a proper reporting procedure by the Government within the terms of the original Act.

The views and needs of indigenous peoples obviously are the subject of agreement and debate at the time when the World Bank enters into development arrangements with the nations to which it will offer assistance. Clearly, proposed new subparagraph (2) (c) (iii) would be encompassed by the general purpose of the Act. The specific reporting requirement provides, in the most general of terms, a means by which information could be provided to the Parliament.

We have a further amendment which was designed to fit in with the Democrat amendment and to draw attention to the fact that there is a need for assessment of the bank's managerial efficiency and financial and economic effectiveness in carrying out the purposes as set down in the article from which I have just quoted. Our amendment covers the very points I have just been describing. I move:
Proposed paragraph 7 (2) (c), insert the following paragraphs:

``(c) an assessment of the managerial efficiency, and financial and economic effectiveness, of the Bank in carrying out its purposes as provided for in Article 1 of the Articles of Agreement set out in Schedule 2 to the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947;

``(d) an assessment of the managerial efficiency, and financial and economic effectiveness, of the Association in carrying out its purposes as provided for in Article 1 of the Articles of Agreement set out in the Schedule of the International Development Association Act 1960; and

``(e) an assessment of the managerial efficiency, and financial and economic effectiveness, of the Corporation in carrying out its purpose as provided for in Schedule 1 of the Articles of Agreement set out in the first Schedule of the International Finance Corporation Act 1955.''.
The Liberal and National parties will not be supporting proposed paragraph 7 (2) (c) of the Democrat amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be in order if a few words were added to the amendment which Senator Messner has circulated which simply said `and leave out clause 7 (2) (c)'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite happy to amend my amendment to that effect. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed paragraph 7 (c) (c), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraphs:

``(c) an assessment of the managerial efficiency, and financial and economic effectiveness, of the Bank in carrying out its purposes as provided for in Article 1 of the Articles of Agreement set out in Schedule 2 to the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947;

``(d) an assessment of the managerial efficiency, and financial and economic effectiveness, of the Association in carrying out its purposes as provided for in Article 1 of the Articles of Agreement set out in the Schedule of the International Development Association Act 1960; and

``(e) an assessment of the managerial efficiency, and financial and economic effectiveness, of the Corporation in carrying out its purpose as provided for in Article 1 of the Articles of Agreement set out in the first Schedule of the International Finance Corporation Act 1955.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under those circumstances the Government regards these amendments as being superfluous, but the amendment circulated by Senator Messner does give some focus to the far more nebulous propositions that were in the original amendments. The Government will support Senator Messner's amendment to the original amendment, but we will not support the amended amendment. However, I gather from Senator Messner's comments the Opposition senators will support it. Under those circumstances, and should that be correct, I will not bother to call a division. We regard the amendment, even in its amended form, as superfluous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats would have been happy to include the amendment moved by Senator Messner in our amendment. However, I indicate that we will certainly oppose what I presume will be the new wording, if it is circulated at all, which I imagine is now that clause 7 (2) (c) be left out and in its place be inserted the amendment circulated by Senator Messner.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend repeating what has been debated at some length. At the second reading stage, I raised the question of the International Monetary Fund Act annual report last year and discussed it in some detail. If honourable senators had bothered reading it they would know that not only has this Government not reported on those items, but also neither has any previous government. The only item in this particular annual report that is anywhere near it is the inclusion of some communiques of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development governors. Those communiques, of course, are compressed documents that obviously express a carefully worded approach after a lot of work has been done behind the scenes. They do not spell out the type of thing that we were looking for by way of our amendment. It was not provided last year; it was not provided the year before and nor has it been provided since 1947. There is no reason why it would be now. This is the only chance that this Parliament would have to enforce that. We will oppose the amendment in the form in which I presume it is now before the Chair.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Messner's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

MINISTER FOR EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION
AND TRAINING
Parliament House, Canberra, ACT, 2600
Mr Julian Beale
Shadow Minister for Education
Parliament House
Canberra
Dear Mr Beale
I refer to our recent discussions concerning the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Bill 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, when the Senate was debating the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Bill 1988, put forward two amendments which were adopted by the Senate and which subsequently became contentious between the Senate and the House of Representatives. Because there are some important broader principles involved, I feel that it is incumbent on me, on behalf of the Opposition, briefly to remind the Committee of the issues at stake at that time and subsequently when the Senate sat to hear the response of the House of Representatives a week later. I shall then outline when the Opposition is prepared to support the motion that is now before the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: In May 1988 the Government, as part of its mini-Budget, decided to cut grants to non-government business colleges-that is, to cut entirely the whole category of $6m made available to these technical and further education (TAFE) type non-government business colleges. The Opposition rejects this policy decision. We do not believe that it is a sound decision. We do not support the decision as we do not believe it is in the best interests of the provision of business skills, especially in respect of stenographers and the women who take stenographic courses. For more than 50 years the best provision of stenographer skills has been by non-government business colleges. Even where there have recently grown up similar courses in government-owned TAFE colleges, there is not the capacity in such colleges to provide the skills to sufficient numbers of persons to meet the nation's needs in this area.

The Government has not brought forward any assessment other than to accept that Australia, in all its States, depends on non-government business colleges, especially for the training of stenographers and persons in business skills. Therefore, to cut out arbitrarily from all recurrent funding these important non-government business colleges was seen by the Opposition to be unacceptable. The Government rethought the matter when this Bill was being formulated in the latter part of 1988 and decided to leave in a transitional $1.5m because the cut would have made it difficult, even in the transition period, for these colleges to remain viable with the enrolments to which they had already committed themselves.

I remind honourable senators that students who attend these business colleges have in the main attended government secondary schools, the taxpayer having provided 100 per cent of the cost of their courses. Other school leavers who go on to tertiary study, whether in TAFE, universities or colleges of advanced education, undertake their courses, in the main, with 100 per cent support from the taxpayer. Why should there be this discrimination against the students undertaking stenography and other business studies courses? It comes down to the fact that the Hawke Labor Government has an ideological difficulty with supporting non-government business colleges. Various Ministers for education, particularly the Minister before the present one, have come out with all manner of ideologically framed statements against the Bond University and against any kind of initiative by non-government educational institutions in the area of post-school education. Yet for a century this country has been served well by bodies such as these non-government business colleges, theological colleges, church-run teachers colleges, independent non-government agricultural colleges, and the providers of a wide variety of adult education courses that are entirely provided without the Government's owning the college or the training institution. No-one during the debate in the Senate or in the House of Representatives has denied that the particular expertise that has been developed by these non-government business colleges over many decades is other than the best available in this country. The third point is that 95 per cent of students undertaking the courses in non-government business colleges are women and are more likely than other tertiary students to have such low recurrent incomes as to be eligible for Austudy benefits if they were available to them. We have a deserving group of school leavers going on to important tertiary training, going to the colleges that provide that training in the best available way, being denied by an arbitrary decision in the nature of a financial stricture, being just cut off the books by the Hawke Labor Government. The failure of the Federal Government to give any support to these students and the colleges concerned was unacceptable to the Opposition in November and December last year, and it is still unacceptable.

When this Bill was first considered in the Senate we moved these amendments successfully. Two amendments were passed at the time. The first, which at the time was called amendment (2), was to remove certain words from clause 12 of the Bill. It would have had the effect of reinstating the level of support that had previously been available-that is, $6m a year. The second amendment, which was then called amendment (3), was to delete clause 13 entirely. It was necessary to proceed with that amendment only if the previous amendment was passed because the deletion of clause 13 meant that it was no longer necessary to make available the $1.5m. It certainly was not our intention to restore the $6m and then, through clause 13, have the $1.5m as well, to make a total of $7.5m. So the effect of the two amendments was to make available $6m instead of the Government's $1.5m.

The Bill went back to the House of Representatives with the Senate's amendments. I will later outline why the Senate's amendments were put in the form of amendments rather than requests for amendments. The House of Representatives considered the Senate's amendments, decided not to agree with them and sent the Bill back to us. This led to a deadlock between the two Houses on this Bill which, in all, provides $313m for technical and further education for the 1989 year.

It is my strong view that the Government dug in its heels on this one Bill rather than on the other six Bills that made up the education package at that time because the other six Bills amounted to some $16 billion in funds for educational purposes, to higher educational institutions and schools in the main, for the next three and four years. If these had been delayed there would have been serious consequences in terms of the recurrent support for schools, universities, colleges of advanced education and institutes of technology. However, only one Bill of the seven, the TAFE Bill, related to 1989 only. In the main it related to capital money provision, for which there were well-laid plans in the States. By and large the money required for the recurrent needs of technical and further education institutions is provided by the States, so the Government had in its pocket the knowledge that to delay this Bill by three months would not be to the enormous disadvantage of the technical and further education sector in this country.

I believe that the Government was quite facetious in putting up the white flag and agreeing to the Senate's amendments with respect to the other six Bills while, with something of macho self-assertion, members of the other place tried to tackle the clear resolve of the Senate-that is, the clear resolve of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, which have a majority in this place-on the TAFE Bill. They were concerned about the Government's ability to win on a policy matter and they were concerned not to give way to the Senate's clear decision against the Government which had an iron majority of numbers in the House of Representatives. The Government did not put up the white flag on the matter, but chose to have it stand over as a point of drama because the matter could be delayed by a few months without any real disaster occurring. It was a point of drama. The Government said to the Senate, `We will give in to you with regard to the six other education Bills, but on this one we want to create a bit of drama and try to assert our view'. Clearly, the Senate is more mature than that and will not allow the Government to see the technical and further education colleges of Australia suffer a delay in their capital moneys of some $313m.

The proposal of the Opposition offered a constructive way to break the deadlock. We urged on the Government that there be an extension of Austudy payments to students in these non-government business colleges, not only for 1989 but for the course of study of any student who began in 1989 so that, in effect, the Austudy would extend to 1990. This extension of Austudy to non-government business students will lead to a benefit commensurate with that which we were seeking to give by direct grants to the institutions involved. (Extension of time granted) I thank the Committee and I thank you, Mr Chairman. I thank my colleagues who are hanging on my every word, wanting to hear the outline of the present situation and the creative proposal that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have made to break this impasse.

We are aware that the Government is anxious to save face. We want to make sure that non-government business college students are assisted in continuing their courses during 1989 and 1990. These courses are of value to the nation and to the individual students concerned. That is why we are glad to see that the Government has accepted this initiative. The Government has said, `Yes, we will give the additional resources in the form of Austudy payments to these non-government business college students'.

I thank the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, for incorporating in his remarks the letter written by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, giving that undertaking. We look forward to the change of the Student Assistance Regulations as soon as is practicable so that there is a clear knowledge amongst the affected students that the Austudy payments are available to them. We note that those Austudy payments are to be backdated to 1 January this year.

It is our expectation that every student in these non-government business college courses who believes himself or herself to be eligible because of personal or family financial circumstances ought to apply as soon as is practicable to gain Austudy for this academic year and for that payment to be backdated to 1 January. The letter from the Minister also sets out that there is a review under way into provisions for Austudy. It is our expectation that the review will incorporate a sympathetic approach to this arrangement. There is no expectation on the part of this place that this will be an undertaking for only one year. Rather the expectation is that it will have a definite effect for one year, and a likely continuity thereafter, in the context of the terms of that wider Austudy review.

The Opposition wants to break the deadlock and see that this money is released for the benefit of all technical and further education colleges around Australia. We want to make it entirely clear that, with the concurrence of the Democrats, we did our utmost to persuade the Government to retain the $6m level of funding to the institutions. Instead of that, we have now gained, as a direct concession from the Government, a similar amount of assistance which will be made available through the means of the Austudy extensions.

I conclude by referring to the Senate amendments. They were not a request, because, despite advice that was given to some members of the House of Representatives including the Minister, Mr Dawkins-we, in the Opposition, do not believe that the form of amendments 2 and 3 to this Bill is contrary to the provisions of section 53 of the Constitution. My colleague Senator Hill will refer more directly in this debate to this matter. I would like to refer entirely favourably to the advice that has been more fully made available by the Clerk of the Senate. At the time of the amendments being moved, the Clerk of the Senate and his assistants gave very direct advice that it was appropriate-notwithstanding our own Standing Orders or the provisions of the Constitution-that we should move by way of amendment rather than by way of request. This advice concurred with our own view of the matter. Accordingly that procedure was followed. Because it is a matter that is of importance to the Senate and to the whole of the Parliament, the Clerk has gone over the precedents in this matter. I commend entirely the paper that he has made available.

I note that this matter was most carefully debated in this Senate in 1903, some 86 years ago. The two main contributors to that debate were two South Australian senators. One was Senator Sir Richard Baker, a free trade senator from South Australia who was in this chamber from 1901 to 1906. The other Senator Sir Josiah Symon, also a free trade senator from South Australia, who was here from 1901 to 1913. In the important precedent of the debate in 1903, which was on a sugar bill, the points that were made and established became the foundation on which Senator Hill and I-also two South Australian senators-have continued to build. It is entirely appropriate for the Senate to consider as amendments those aspects of a Bill we believe can lead to the improvement of legislation, whether by a change of wording to express a change of policy or whether by widening the discretion of a Minister in the making of payments. No decisions of this type involved in the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Bill transgress section 53 of the Constitution, which provides that the Senate may not amend a Bill so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people. The interpretation of the third part of section 53 must be that there is a requirement that a request have the necessary effect of clearly and directly increasing expenditure under an appropriation. Any increase in government spending must not be just a possibility but must be a matter of necessity; a matter that is clear and direct.

The consequence otherwise could well be-we would totally resist this in the Senate-that it would be regarded as against the provisions of section 53 of the Constitution for the Senate to amend almost anything that was before it because it may have the consequence of indirectly leading to some additional charge or burden on the people. If it is indirect, clearly it should not prevent the Senate from considering the merits of legislation that is before it and making up its mind on the merits of the case, even on the merits of its view about policy, but only where it is totally direct and clear that there would be an extra charge or burden should there be an amendment to legislation here that takes the form of a request to the House of Representatives.

I will leave my colleague, Senator Hill, to refer to this important issue in his subsequent remarks. It is clear to me that members of the House of Representatives in their report to us as to their reasons for not agreeing to our amendment and the Minister, Mr Dawkins, in his references were using this as a matter of rhetoric to try to bolster the Government's own argument, which is unacceptable to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I met the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) last week with Julian Beale, who is the Opposition shadow Minister for education. Senator Teague's recounting of the outcome of that particular meeting was somewhat more sanguine than mine is. Having been through an exercise with the States grants Bills under the Fraser Government when Senator Peter Baume was the Minister for Education, I remember that the same type of blackmail was used. Again with Senator Susan Ryan and the States grants Bills the same type of blackmail was used. It has to be admitted that by and large at the end of the day this chamber has very little leverage with regard to States grants Bills. It might be that the people in the community are not quite sure why that is, but it becomes very clear when the entire funding of one of the levels of education in this country depends on a particular Bill. The Senate can actually hold that Bill up if it wishes, but I think that it would be at its peril.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also has other procedural devices, one of which it took a few days ago to split the Bills and introduce the purely technical and further education (TAFE) component and the private business college component as separate Bills so that the TAFE component would have a passage through the chamber since there was no dispute concerning that matter. The other Bill would languish in the House of Representatives, in the Senate or the large space in between.

Our view is that this is a compromise. It is an unhappy compromise because it still fails to address the fundamental issue. The Australian Democrats supported the Opposition's amendment with regard to the private business colleges-I suppose some people may find it odd that we would support private business colleges-quite precisely because of the group of people who were involved; that is, 95 per cent are young women under the age of 20. They are overwhelmingly from state schools and are overwhelmingly eligible for Austudy.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are also eligible for TAFE in most cases.

—Senator Zakharov interjects that they are eligible for TAFE. That is perfectly true, except that TAFE has not been able to offer them the places and that is very clear. It has not had the money, it has not had the resources, and it cannot even fulfil the demands which are currently made on it. It certainly could not take these types of demands; if it could, there would not be a debate. In fact, if it could the income of most of these people would dictate that they would go to TAFE and not to private business colleges. So these colleges have been offering a good career to a group of people who have not necessarily clicked terribly well in the schooling context. At a later stage they often do go back to further study. If they had chosen to remain within the schooling context they would have been funded 100 per cent by the Commonwealth. They are deserving of support.

SPEECH.PARA: These people are now able to have Austudy for a year. I think that that is important because it seems to have been the major reason for the very alarming drop in enrolments in those courses. We have a modicum of support for the business colleges that have dealt with this matter so successfully over a considerable number of years. Where we go from here and what is likely to happen next year is a matter of interest. One hopes that we may see a liberalisation of the funding for TAFE so that it will be in a position to offer more extensive courses to people in clerical areas. If that does not occur, then I think there will be a significant educational loss for these people. That would be an enormous shame not only for those people but also for the country.

We are not happy with the outcome. It is a compromise which enables these people to get though this year, but it does not present us with a long term view. Austudy will operate from 1 January to 31 December. There is no guarantee, except for the people who enrol before 31 December, that it will go through to next year. We certainly have a fairly firm guarantee of no continuing funding for the private business colleges which offer those types of courses. Honourable senators should remember that this funding is not for overseas students; it is essentially for 10-week-type courses in the areas that I have already outlined.

There is continuing concern on our part that we have not resolved the policy issues. I am mindful of a letter that was written to me by the Minister and his undertaking that he would look at this whole business of Austudy, particularly with regard to the developing types of courses that may be around through a whole range of institutions. It seems fairly reasonable that, if those people are eligible and the courses are not offered elsewhere, that is a reasonable base to say, `Well, there is at least a prima facie case that they should be funded in that way'.

With regard to the general matter of private institutions, I think that in part that is a red herring inasmuch as the Government, not only by way of amendment but also by way of legislation, has often engaged in grandfathering exercises, as they are called, whereby a particular policy initiative that arose and was carried forward over a number of years was not treated as a precedent for a wider break-out in an area. Seemingly that has also been rejected. I think that that is probably a pity. I hope that the Government does not simply wash its hands of this group of people but that it actively seeks to make sure that education is provided from here on in in a way that is commensurate with the types of financial resources that one could expect to be available for that group of women. If the Government does not do that, I think it could very well stand accused of selling out a group of people who I would have thought, at least on the basis of the Government's own agenda for women, it was dedicated to support. I hope that this will be looked at. I hope that it will be pursued vigorously. I hope that, with the absence from the Ministry of former Senator Susan Ryan, who had a great deal of interest in these things and pursued them with a fair amount of vigour, this will not be pushed aside by the Government as just another of those items that one can wave one's arm at and say, `This is a private sector exercise'. It is not. It is a provision that has been offered by the private sector to a group of people who would normally be found within the state sector in TAFE, if there were any availability. That is where they would have gone. If most of them were available to gain Austudy, one can certainly assume, fairly clearly, that their resources are not vast.

I assume that the Government will follow through on that; I hope that it will. I hope that, when we come again later this year to States grants, TAFE and tertiary assistance Bills, we will have an opportunity of furthering this debate and of seeing in a report from the Government precisely where it has gone with its deliberations set down in the letter to me and to the Opposition spokesperson on education, Julian Beale.
