TALK.START.PARA: —The Administrative Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 involves amendments to four different Acts of Parliament: firstly, the Public Works Committee Act 1969; secondly, the Australian Protective Service Act 1987; thirdly, the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973; and, fourthly, the Parliament House Construction Authority Act 1979. I do not wish to deal at great length with all these changes, many of which are unexceptional and which involve sensible alterations.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing that these amendments do is to recognise that the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works, which is a very effective and important committee of the Parliament, works under a very heavy burden. There has been some controversy in the Parliament about the extent to which the Public Works Committee should be provided with assistance. I am glad that the Government is recognising that the work it does is of great substance and that it should be assisted, by way of these amendments, in lessening some of its burden and in making clearer what it should be looking at.

One of these amendments ensures that works carried out under the deferred payment arrangements that the Government has undertaken come within the purview of the Public Works Committee. I would like to discuss this a little because there are many instances now-and the Budget Papers reveal them-where the Government is, in effect, hiding the extent to which it is spending large amounts of public money on major new buildings, such as the government offices in Wollongong or the government offices in Parramatta. This Government, which goes to the people saying, `We have cut government spending enormously', is in effect hiding the extent to which it has failed to cut government spending so dramatically because it is going ahead with these major projects for which it then pays over an extended period; in other words, it leaves the bill to be picked up by the Budget down the track. The interesting thing is that in the past, it appears, these kinds of works carried out under the deferred payment arrangements were not subject to Public Works Committee scrutiny. I am very glad indeed that the Government is now bringing these matters under the control of the Public Works Committee.

The main matter I want to talk about deals with the parliamentary zone and the Parliament House Construction Authority, but before I get to that I should just mention that the legislation also covers amendments to the Australian Protective Service Act to extend the list of specified offences for which protective service officers have the power to arrest without warrant. These offences, such as escaping from lawful custody, aiding a person to escape from lawful custody, or rescuing a person by force from lawful custody, were recently created by amendments to the Crimes Act 1914. These amendments are essentially consequential to the Crimes Act amendments and, of course, the Opposition is quite happy to support them. We also support amendments to the Commonwealth Grants Commission to provide the option of appointing a part time chairman to that Commission.

The point I would like to deal with, though, relates to the Parliament House Construction Authority. This legislation will reduce the number of members on the Board of the Parliament House Construction Authority from six to three. That amendment clearly is in recognition of the facts that the new Parliament House has almost been completed and the services of many of the people on the Board are no longer needed to supervise this major building. The three members to be removed from the Board will be the National Capital Development Commissioner and two others yet to be named.

It is worth making the point at this moment that the Board has worked very hard in very trying conditions. I noticed that Mr Morokoff, the Chairman, was quite properly rewarded with membership of the Order of Australia in the Australia Day honours list. I am certain that all senators will join me in congratulating him on that award, as all senators clearly will join me in congratulating Mr Gordon Peatey, the Chief Executive Officer of the Parliament House Construction Authority, who also received such an award and who next month will retire from his very arduous job. I say that, having been a major critic of Mr Peatey and the Parliament House Construction Authority.

I do not resile in any way from that criticism. Now, at the time when the Bill comes in reducing that Board, we see some of the consequences of the extraordinary manner in which this building was constructed. I am not going to rake over the old coals of the consequences of the fast track building method and how it added multi millions of dollars to the cost of this building. But it is worth saying that one of the major problems we face in this building and one of the major causes of millions of dollars of unnecessary expenditure is that in so many instances the architects of this place rediscovered the wheel. They were so determined to get a finish which was up to the standard that they sought and which they believed was only fitting for a building of this status that they refused to go down the track of getting fittings and equipment which were readily available, no matter how good the quality.

Instead, they designed matters going down to door knobs which were once-off and specially designed and cost many times the amount that similar items of similar quality would have cost and which were readily available without the extraordinary specifications that were introduced. I say once again that this was at immense and unnecessary cost, which was met by the people of Australia, in building this very significant public structure.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not take any notice of the users' needs.

—As Senator Watson said, they did not take any notice of the users' needs, either. My criticism of this place is not that I am opposed to the existence of this significant, very impressive public building-although I do concede that I have reservations about the extent to which this place is more of a major public building than it is a workable parliament. It would seem to me-perhaps this is selfish because I have to work here as a parliamentarian-that the task of the Board of the Parliament House Construction Authority and the architects in building this place was primarily to build it as a parliament. But that objective seems to have been way down the list of objectives that were before those people who were responsible for creating this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The ostentatious waste of space between our offices forces us to get incredibly fit when trying to have any kind of interaction with our colleagues. I know that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), from the far off ministerial wing no doubt finds a diminished need for using an exercise bike because every time the bells ring she has an enormous distance to cover. Those distances are largely unnecessary, as one can establish very clearly by looking at the massive amounts of waste space in this place. Once again I say that this is at enormous cost to the people of Australia.

I am concerned that in the little over six months that we have been in this building-we have had only the Budget session before starting this session-the problems we are having do not seem to be simply those of settling into a new building. All new buildings have major problems. It would be ridiculous for anyone to say that this Parliament House should somehow, magically be free of problems simply because it cost $1,060m. It is the biggest and most expensive building ever in this country's history. It is one of the most expensive buildings in the world. It is incredible in that sort of situation that there has not been tighter control of a whole range of things.

I do not want to go over once again the detailed auditor's report which demonstrated the lack of cost control in many areas of this building's construction. But I do want to say how extraordinary it is that, when the architects or the Parliament House Construction Authority, or whoever was responsible, decided that the expenditure restraints the Government had imposed would involve cuts in completing this building, the areas where it would be most inconvenient to the inhabitants of this place were those that are cut, and those which would be of minimal inconvenience to the occupants by not being completed, but which would look nicer to the visitors, were those that received the money.

Honourable senators will notice that, outside the Senate chamber in the areas that lead to the party rooms of both parties, there is gravel thrown about on the ground instead of a completed courtyard. We have been told that that was because the Government reduced the amount of money available to complete those things. In the other courtyards, where members of parliament, to my knowledge, do not walk and are never likely to walk, there are beautifully finished courtyards with granite paths which look lovely but have no effective, meaningful use. Yet in the one area where we need some effective paving, outside the chambers and our Party rooms, there is gravel because, frankly, it cannot be seen from the public areas and people cannot say, `Why didn't the architects, the Parliament House Construction Authority, the Government or someone finish that off?'. The only people who are inconvenienced are the members and senators of this place.

It seems ludicrous. I might add that the gravel is then trodden onto the expensive flooring of this place, quite frankly, because of incompetence. I will not use other adjectives. But it seems to me to be a deliberate and determined decision that the people to be inconvenienced by a reduction in the amount of money to be spent here are the occupants and users of this building, not the people who come to look at it and go away.

The reason I concentrate on such a small issue-the fact that gravel has been trodden through the beautiful parquetry floors, destroying them-is that it seems to me to reflect an attitude in this place which I find unacceptable. I am particularly irritated that the public places of this building have at all times taken precedence over the working requirements of a good Parliament House. For example, this chamber is not a patch on the chamber in the old Parliament House. Its timber walls gave a feeling of solidity and reliability. This chamber, with its panelled textile walls gives no feeling of anything other than that one day, with average luck, the walls may fall down. Maybe it is appropriate while this Government is in office that the walls give no feeling of stability. I trust that that analogy is appropriate.

At a Senate Estimates committee hearing last year I asked numerous questions about who would pay for all the problems that have occurred since we came into this place. I think that everyone is aware of the massive indentation of the parquetry caused by stiletto heels. At Senate Estimates I asked what would happen, who would pay to get it fixed and when it would be fixed. I was told at that time that the Great Hall would be sanded. That has subsequently been denied. It certainly did not happen over the Christmas break. It seems to me that this Parliament is entitled to know who will pay to fix up all the things that have not been successful. As I understand it, the ceiling tiles in many areas of this place have been rehung, not once or twice but three times. Who has paid for that? Were they dangerously installed, as was alleged by one of my colleagues, who asked the people reinstalling the material what they were doing mucking around with the ceiling tiles again? He was told that they had been dangerously installed.

Anyone who has had a good look at the carpets on the second floor will have found that they look stained somehow. I understand that the glue is coming through the carpets because they have been steam cleaned nigh unto death through having been mishandled. We can look at the whole question of maintenance. Several of the beautiful black marble blocks that pave this place have been torn up in recent times because of some problem underneath them, broken in the process and replaced by marble blocks which appear to be light grey rather than black and look hideous. In passing I ask why this cannot be done properly. What has gone wrong? Who paid for it, and why was there not a stock of similar marble? Why, when it was pulled up, did it have to be broken?

The list-I am picking out only a few items-goes on and on forever. Water pipes have burst in many areas because they were not properly joined, involving flooding of many of the offices. The staff in particular have been most inconvenienced by that. As a result of flooding, some of the parquetry has curled up. We have had the extraordinary situation of four lavishly equipped subkitchens, as they are called, having their equipment pulled out because apparently there is no real demand for them and no staff resources to use them anyway. I wonder what sort of planning went on to bring about such a situation.

I am concerned about what will happen in the management of this building. I am concerned about who will rectify the things that have gone wrong and who will pay. I notice plenty of door sealers falling off around the place. Until there is clear evidence that someone is taking a strong and determined position in the new Parliament House-someone who has the status of client-we will keep on not getting answers to these questions. I can assure the Joint House Department and the Parliament House Construction Authority that at the Senate Estimates hearings in April I will ask a whole host of questions, which I hope will be answered satisfactorily, about what has gone wrong, what is going wrong and what is likely to go wrong with this building.

The failure to maintain the Sydney Opera House has involved the State Government of New South Wales in massive-multimillions of dollars-worth-expenditure. I want to be assured-I think the Senate has every right to be assured-that the external, and total maintenance of this building is not only adequate but capable of ensuring that there will be no sudden and unexpected multimillion dollar attack on taxpayers' pockets because things have not been done properly. One of the major problems faced in the maintenance of a building such as this has been the once-off nature of specially designed equipment and specially designed furniture-specially designed everything-that is simply not available off the shelf for replacement or repair purposes. For that reason I hope that the changes being made to the Parliament House Construction Authority under this legislation will be matched by changes within the administration of the Parliament itself in the manner and status of the management of this place.

This is a major public building. It is a public building that requires an immense staff and immense management. I would ask that the same enthusiasm which has prompted the Government to introduce the Administrative Services Legislation Amendment Bill, which has the Opposition's support, also be directed towards a close examination-certainly closer than we have seen so far-of the administration and maintenance of this Parliament House.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: World Sheep and Wool Congress-Women-Namibia-Defence Policy

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over recent years many in the media and public life have played down the importance of the wool industry to Australia. I wish to draw the attention of honourable senators to an extremely important event which took place in Tasmania last week. I am very proud that we in Tasmania were able to host the second World Sheep and Wool Congress which focused worldwide recognition on our wool and sheep industries. The far-sighted goals of and the heavy groundwork preparation for the congress to be held in Australia had the driving force of three key players in Mr Keith McLauchlan, Mr Richard Lawrence and Mr Ian Downie and others, whose determined lobbying at Edmonton, Canada, in 1986 with a selection of sheep of various breeds from leading studs won Tasmania the right to host the Congress. Keith McLauchlan spearheaded the project, built around him an enthusiastic and capable team comprising Bruce Connor, Graham Foster, the managing director of Combined Rural Traders Ltd, Mark Barnett and Pat Headlam and formed committee contacts overseas. The appointment of Mr Ron Limb as executive director, with his extensive background in the media and agriculture, and with responsibility for the overall coordination of this event, further ensured its success.

SPEECH.PARA: The Congress symposium brought together some of the world's leading authorities on sheep and wool. The Princess Royal, when she spoke at the opening of the Congress at the Wrest Point convention centre on Monday, 27 February, said:
The World Sheep and Wool Congress has come to the right place.

Seventeen countries and 1,000 delegates were registered at the conference, which had its itinerary divided between the north and south of the island. Tasmania has long had a reputation as a fine wool producer and a centre of excellence. This has been borne out recently by the huge prices commanded for wool at the recent wool sales in Launceston, when the Japanese Fujii family paid 300,850c per kilo of saxon merino superfine wool from the Connorville property near Cressy.

We were most privileged to have had an array of well-qualified and respected speakers both from overseas and around Australia. A considerable range of international experiences, skills and specialised knowledge were shared with us on diverse topics. Sheep and goat breeding was the topic of Dr Moroz from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Dr Brian Bagnell from the United States of America spoke on the development of markets for agricultural products. Dr Ted Jones, also from the United States, spoke on markets for woollen fabrics and sheepmeats. Mr R. Campbell from New Zealand delivered an address on prime lambs for export markets. Speakers came from every state of the Commonwealth, and all contributed greatly to the quality of the symposium.

The dedication of these people to the wool and sheep industry and their efforts to improve and share their knowledge was much appreciated and provided an insight into the concern of sheep farmers all over the world. In addition to the specialist lectures, guests were shown various stud properties and there was a trade fair in Launceston. The trade fair was a most important sheep breeders event, where the quality and importance of sheepmeat was highly acclaimed. The fair concentrated on the technical side of the industry, with producers being able to display the latest developments in a range of areas from genetic engineering to marketing. It was an opportunity for them to show their knowledge in so many areas such as animal health; genetic engineering, the biological control of diseases, electronics for the sheep industry, fencing, shearing, state of the art wool processing, other farm orientated equipment and wool crafts such as spinning and weaving. Producers exhibited their wares to people from all over the world who are totally dedicated to the sheep industry.

The wool and carcass exhibit was truly of international standard. Credit must go the organisers of the Congress for the results they have achieved since winning the right to host the Congress in Tasmania. It is also important to acknowledge the support received from the Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who took a high profile at the conference, as well as the unstinting support of the Tasmanian Government, especially the State Department of Agriculture, and the Tasmanian Development Authority. The support of my Senate colleague Senator Paul Calvert as President of the Royal Agricultural Society of Tasmania was very much appreciated. The Society generously underwrote a number of important Congress activities.

The wool and sheep congress was not an end in itself but a big step in the continuation of further development in a most important and vital industry all over the world, as evidenced by the number of participants and the countries they represent. The Congress will in the future be seen as an appropriate vehicle for the development and maintenance of information channels where exchange of information and technology is allowed to flow and opportunities for trade will be created and fostered. I would like especially to mention the scores of Tasmanian woolgrowers and their families who gave countless hours in a wholly voluntary capacity to ensure that the Congress was the success it was. They put a great deal of effort into every aspect of the event, especially making a warm welcome to the many overseas guests who attended.

The World Sheep and Wool Congress shows that wool is still a fundamental element of the national economy and lifestyle. The staging of this international Congress was a coup for Tasmania, recognising the importance of the industry in the State and nationally, and the role that wool plays in the international arena.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put on record a few remarks about the hypocrisy of some members of the Opposition in quoting slabs of material from a commentator whose writing would not generally be supported on their side of the chamber. Eva Cox has a long record as a commentator on social and women's issues and her comments have been taken out of context in recent days. The Age article from which Senator Vanstone quoted today expressed concerns about marginalisation of women. The Opposition's actions in selecting a male spokesman on women's issues indicates that it also does not take women's issues seriously. It is mischievous and dishonest for Opposition members to quote selectively from this article.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, and even more bizarre, was Senator Walters's use of the same article last week. Senator Walters's record in these areas has been one of almost total opposition to any programs which recognise that women have suffered and are still suffering disadvantages. If members of the Opposition were vocal and enthusiastic supporters of affirmative action, of special programs for women and of the existence of the special units for women, such as the Office of the Status of Women, their sudden interest in women might be more credible.

The Opposition has shown a complete disregard of most of the programs that a feminist such as Eva Cox would support. Its policies on income splitting and on tax rebates for child-care and its support for the traditional family indicate that its only interest in this area is to use, quite cynically, any material which might embarrass the Government. Considering the Opposition's poor record in this area, its use of writings by radical feminists such as Eva Cox to criticise the Government is very bizarre. The Opposition has failed dismally to support many of the measures that have been introduced by the present Government to assist women.

There are many problems with any government trying to address women's issues. Most of these problems arise from the mostly male and patriarchal systems which still dominate the political and bureaucratic systems. However, while ever the corridors of power are largely inhabited by men, women will find much to criticise. Nonetheless, my criticisms arise from a desire to make further changes to enhance the position of women. They stem from a belief that the present Government moves too slowly and is not sensitive enough to women's issues. For example, it was noted by the women at the Women's Tax Convention on Saturday that it was the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr John Kerin, who opened the conference. It was felt that the Government might have taken the Convention more seriously and sent along a senior finance Minister to open it. However, the women who want to see change towards a less discriminatory society, one which gives women the fair go that men have, are not supporting the sometimes antediluvian views promoted by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments about the changing situation in Namibia and the announcement that Australia will be sending a small force of 300 troops there as part of the United Nations Transitional Assistance Group. I welcome this initiative, which will assist Namibia in reaching independence after more than 100 years of colonial rule by Germany and South Africa. This is one of the best uses for Australia's military forces-to be available for United Nations peacekeeping missions, rather like the Irish, Swedish and Austrian military forces. That role is largely possible because those countries are perceived as neutral by the world community. For Australia, this is the tenth contribution it has made to United Nations peacekeeping forces over 42 years. It is commendable. It is also good that the vehicles going with the Australian group have been repainted the international colours of the United Nations rather than drab army green.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, one of the problems with this operation is the cost. I note that South Africa will be supplying much of the fuel and other supplies and equipment for the United Nations (UN) peacekeeping force. While I know this is largely because of the high costs of taking such goods from outside the continent, I would point out the concern of those who believe that South Africa will use this opportunity to do everything it can to influence the outcome of the forthcoming elections in favour of its own candidates and against the wishes of the majority of the people of Namibia.

Many have died or had to leave their country as refugees in the 23-year war against South Africa. It has been one of Africa's forgotten wars. Like those in Eritrea, the Western Sahara, Chad and Mozambique. It is not without significance that there are those in this Parliament who have criticised the Namibian Liberation movements like the South West Africa People's Organisation (SWAPO) for many years. They have confused Marxism with nationalism and mistakenly have argued that the freedom movements were inspired more by Moscow than the Christian churches. In fact, it was the Lutheran, Anglican and Catholic churches which had a great influence on the early struggle for independence rather than ideas from books which are not even available in South Africa or Namibia because they are banned.

It was apparently all right for Australia to fight with the Soviet Union against Nazi Germany 50 years ago. But it was not all right for SWAPO to get support from the Soviet Union to fight Adolf Hitler's successors in Pretoria, while the West tacitly supported white South Africa in its illegal occupation of Namibia in defiance of UN resolutions. The UN has consistently supported the cause of liberation for Namibia since an Anglican priest, the Reverend Michael Scott, persuaded the member states not to let the South African Government incorporate Namibia into South Africa as a fifth province after a bogus plebiscite at the end of the Second World War.

Australia, to its credit, was the first Western nation to join the UN Council for Namibia and it was this Government which allowed SWAPO to open an information office in Melbourne despite attempts by right wing apologists for apartheid to close it down. I am sorry that the Government refused the fund the office, but at least it resisted calls to close it down by those who confuse liberation movements with terrorism, while supporting state-sanctioned terrorism in other parts of the world such as Central America and the Philippines. I hope that we will be vigilant in making sure that South Africa does not use its position to abuse the agreement which will lead Namibia to independence after free and fair elections for which its people have waited for so long.

I would like to make a plea for more support and understanding for the United Nations organisation which is acting as the third force in this conflict. The world puts a lot of money into military forces-about a trillion dollars this year, I believe. In Namibia there has been a war of attrition for 23 years and in the end it needed negotiating skills and a third party to resolve the conflict non-violently. If the money the world's nations spend on war and preparations for war was spent instead on developing alternative models of conflict resolution and strengthening the UN, then the world would be a much better place. This operation in Namibia nearly fell apart because of the costs, estimated to be approaching $US500m. When one considers that the United States and the Soviet Union alone spend $US1.5 billion a day on the arms race, it really is not very much. It shows that a re-ordering of our priorities is necessary.

Another comparison worth noting is that our contribution to this peacekeeping force represents what we spend on defence against non-existent threats in about one month, although I know there are some people who feel that the Australian defence forces and Kangaroo 89 will fall apart without these 300 men. I commend the Government for its support for the UN in this operation and I would also like to commend the men who, for 12 months, will go to help a people who have waited so long for their freedom. I realise that they will find Grootfontein somewhat different from Holsworthy or their own homes, but I hope they will find life interesting working with a multinational force drawn from Africa, Asia, South America, North America and Europe.

On a different subject, I want to draw attention to an article in the current edition of the Bulletin entitled `Small fish in a big world' in which Alan Renouf, a former Australian ambassador overseas and a former Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs, reflects on the mindlessness of Australian foreign policy. Having just commended the Government for its enlightened view of South Africa, I want to talk for a moment about how we act in relation to our own situation in the Asia-Pacific region and particularly in relation to the United States alliance. Alan Renouf is a person who ought to know what he is talking about. Actually, I think it is probably very embarrassing for the Government to have this kind of thing said by somebody who has been working at such a high level in the Department of Foreign Affairs in the past. The main thrust of his article is that there is very little difference in substance between former Prime Minister Fraser's foreign and defence policies and those that the present Government is espousing. The article states:

At the centre of Prime Minister Bob Hawke's foreign policy is that familiar crutch, the alliance relationship with the US. This has never been stronger, which is truly astonishing, for the US until very recently had, as President, Ronald Reagan-the greatest reactionary to have led that country in modern times. Even this did not deter the enthusiasm of Hawke for the alliance and his government has simply trotted out the so familiar and so misleading account of the `advantages' of the ANZUS pact.
Further on the article states:
In defence, the policy discredited by the Vietnam War-forward defence-has been resurrected by Hawke.
I think that it should really be attributed to Mr Beazley as much as to the Prime Minister, but this is how Alan Renouf sees it:

Fraser started the process, Hawke has continued it with only one change-it is not called `forward defence' any longer. Current defence policy is said to be `self reliance' but, when one looks into it, it amounts to reliance upon the US as before and helping South-East Asian and South Pacific countries so that any menace to Australia will be averted far away from the continent.

Perhaps it makes some sense to ensure that problems do not reach our shores but not by a policy which, in itself, is a contradiction in terms. How can we be self-reliant if we are tied into this very close alliance with the United States? In 1986 the United States announced it would have a 600-ship navy that has since gone by the board; the United States cannot afford it. So now we see Australia filling the gap for the United States Navy in this part of the world and trying to draw New Zealand back into the fold with the Anzac frigate project.

Mr Renouf talks about the very sad fact that Australians generally seem to be very apathetic about foreign policy and defence issues. I think he is absolutely right in that view. As someone who has taken a great interest in those areas, I believe it is sad that most Australians do not seem to have very much concern about these issues. Unfortunately they seem to leave foreign policy and defence issues to the Government, to the defence people on Russell Hill or to a small group of academics who are interested in these issues. These issues are far too important to leave to such groups of people. They are issues that the community at large ought to be involved in and ought to be interested in. A final comment from Mr Renouf is as follows:

Hawke's government has been much more active in the disarmament field, Fraser having been more in favour of armament than disarmament. But all of Hawke's efforts have produced nothing concrete because of the perceived need not to annoy the US. Hence, Hawke has refused the only weapon he has to influence the US-namely, the American `bases' in Australia.

I could not agree more. For example, the very good work that has been done by the disarmament conference representatives in Geneva and New York on the comprehensive test ban has been stymied, thwarted again and again by the US because it is the US that does not want to see a comprehensive test ban. For all of the rhetoric that has gone on, there has been, as Alan Renouf says, no substantive change whatsoever. His article concludes by stating that:

The Opposition('s) . . . principal criticism of Hawke's policy seems to be that the government is not close enough to the US. What an attitude! Australia could only be closer by becoming a state of the American Union to which the US would never agree.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
